revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}} {{Use British English|date=April 2018}} [[File:Royal British Legion's Paper Poppy - white background.jpg|thumb|Royal British Legion remembrance poppy]] The '''remembrance poppy''' is an [[artificial flower]] that has been used since 1921 to commemorate military personnel who have died in war, and represents a common or field poppy, ''[[Papaver rhoeas]]''. Inspired by the [[World War I]] poem "[[In Flanders Fields]]", and promoted by [[Moina Michael]], they were first adopted by the [[American Legion]] to commemorate American soldiers killed in that war. They were then adopted by [[veteran|military veterans]]' groups in parts of the [[British Empire]].
Today, they are mostly used in the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, to commemorate their servicemen and women killed in all conflicts. There, small artificial poppies are often worn on clothing leading up to [[Remembrance Day]]/[[Armistice Day]],<ref name="bbcmagazine">{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-15637074 | title=Who, What, Why: Which countries wear poppies? | first=Rema | last=Rahman | date=9 November 2011 | publisher=BBC News | accessdate=11 May 2018 }}</ref> and poppy [[wreath]]s are often laid at [[war memorial]]s. In Australia and New Zealand, they are also worn on [[Anzac Day]].
The [[Royal British Legion]]'s Poppy Appeal has caused [[#Protests and controversy|some controversy]], with some—including British Army veterans—arguing that it has become excessive, is being used to marshal support behind British military campaigns, and that public figures are pressured to wear poppies.
==Origins== [[File:Field poppy - Papaver rhoeas (12190335083).jpg|thumb|right|The flower of the common or field poppy ''[[Papaver rhoeas]]'', on which the remembrance poppy is based]] [[File:00MoinaMichael.jpg|thumb|right|Moina Michael on a 1948 U.S. commemorative stamp]] The remembrance poppy was inspired by the World War I poem "[[In Flanders Fields]]". Its opening lines refer to the many poppies that were the first flowers to grow in the churned-up earth of soldiers' graves in [[Flanders]], a region of [[Belgium]].<ref name="bbc10nov06">{{cite news | author = | title =Where did the idea to sell poppies come from? | publisher =BBC News | date =10 November 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/6133312.stm | accessdate=18 February 2009}}</ref> It is written from the point of view of the dead soldiers and, in the last verse, they call on the living to continue the conflict.<ref name="fox">Fox, James. "Poppy Politics: Remembrance of Things Present", in ''Cultural Heritage Ethics: Between Theory and Practice''. Open Book Publishers, 2014. pp.23-28</ref> The poem was written by [[Canada|Canadian]] physician, [[John McCrae]], on 3 May 1915 after witnessing the death of his friend, a fellow soldier, the day before. The poem was first published on 8 December 1915 in the [[London]]-based magazine ''[[Punch (magazine)|Punch]]''.
In 1918, [[Moina Michael]], who had taken leave from her professorship at the [[University of Georgia]] to be a volunteer worker for the American [[YMCA Overseas War Secretaries organization]], was inspired by the poem and published a poem of her own called "[[We Shall Keep the Faith]]".<ref name=DLG>{{cite news | author = | title =Moina Michael | publisher =Digital Library of Georgia/[[University of Georgia]] | date = | url =http://georgiainfo.galileo.usg.edu/mmichael.htm | accessdate=18 February 2009}}</ref> In tribute to McCrae's poem, she vowed to always wear a red poppy as a symbol of remembrance for those who fought and helped in the war.<ref name="bbc10nov06"/> At a November 1918 YMCA Overseas War Secretaries' conference, she appeared with a silk poppy pinned to her coat and distributed 25 more to those attending. She then campaigned to have the poppy adopted as a national symbol of remembrance. At a conference in 1920, the National American Legion adopted it as their official symbol of remembrance.<ref name="bbc10nov06"/> At this conference, Frenchwoman Anna E. Guérin<ref>{{cite web|url=https://poppyladymadameguerin.wordpress.com/|title=Madame Guérin|author=Heather A. Johnson|date=6 August 2015|website=WHO PUT THE POPPY ON YOUR LAPEL? MADAME ANNA A. GUÉRIN DID.|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref> was inspired to introduce the artificial poppies commonly used today. In 1921 she sent her poppy sellers to London, where the symbol was adopted by [[Field Marshal (United Kingdom)|Field Marshal]] [[Douglas Haig]], a founder of the [[Royal British Legion]]. It was also adopted by veterans' groups in Canada, Australia and New Zealand.<ref name="bbc10nov06"/> James Fox notes that all of the countries who adopted the remembrance poppy were the "victors" of World War I.<ref name="fox"/>
==Usage== Today, remembrance poppies are mostly used in the United Kingdom, Canada, Australia and New Zealand—countries which were formerly part of the [[British Empire]]—to commemorate their servicemen and women killed in all conflicts. They are used to a lesser extent in the United States.
===Australia=== In Australia, remembrance poppies have been used since 1921 to commemorate Australian soldiers who died in war. On Remembrance Day (11 November) and [[Anzac Day]] (25 April) they are laid at war memorials, and are sold by the [[Returned and Services League of Australia]] (RSL) in return for donations.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Red Poppy - Australian Army|url = http://www.army.gov.au/Our-history/Traditions/The-Red-Poppy|website = www.army.gov.au|accessdate = 10 November 2015}}</ref>
===Canada=== [[File:Poppies by Benoit Aubry of Ottawa.JPG|thumb|Canadian remembrance poppies]] In Canada, the poppy is the official symbol of remembrance worn during the two weeks before 11 November, having been adopted in 1921. The [[Royal Canadian Legion]], which has [[trademark]]ed the image,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion.ca/honour-remember/the-poppy-trademark/|title=The Royal Canadian Legion Poppy Trademark - The Royal Canadian Legion|work=The Royal Canadian Legion|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> suggests that poppies be worn on the left lapel, or as near the heart as possible.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vac-acc.gc.ca/general/sub.cfm?source=teach_resources/poppy |title=Poppy Facts - Veterans Affairs Canada |publisher=Vac-acc.gc.ca |date=21 October 1999 |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref>
Until 1996, poppies were made by disabled veterans in Canada, but they have since been made by a private contractor.<ref>{{cite web |author=Webmaster, Patrick Riley |url=http://www.legion.ca/Poppy/campaign_e.cfm |title=The Royal Canadian Legion |publisher=Legion.ca |date= |accessdate=23 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511063341/http://legion.ca/Poppy/campaign_e.cfm |archivedate=11 May 2012 |df= }}</ref> The Canadian poppies consist of two pieces of moulded plastic covered with [[Flocking (texture)|flocking]] with a pin to fasten them to clothing. At first the poppies were made with a black centre. From 1980 to 2002, the centres were changed to green. Current designs are black only; this change caused confusion and controversy to those unfamiliar with the original design.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rcaf-arc.forces.gc.ca/16w-16e/nr-sp/index-eng.asp?id=180 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=12 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523035823/http://www.rcaf-arc.forces.gc.ca/16w-16e/nr-sp/index-eng.asp?id=180 |archivedate=23 May 2013 |df= }}</ref> In 2007, sticker versions of the poppy were made for children, the elderly, and healthcare and food industry workers.<ref>{{cite news| first =Julia| last =Skikavich| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =New sticker poppies are catching on| url =http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2008/11/05/poppy-stickers.html| work =| publisher =CBC News| id =| pages =| page =| date =5 November 2008| accessdate =12 November 2008| language =| quote =| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20081209042633/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2008/11/05/poppy-stickers.html| dead-url =yes| archivedate =9 December 2008| df =}}</ref> {{anchor|UK}} Canada also issues a cast metal "Canada Remembers" pin featuring a gold maple leaf and two poppies, one representing the fallen and the other representing those who remained on the [[home front]].<ref>[https://docs.google.com/leaf?id=0B3nMfjn73O0gOWE2NDkxMGQtYTRjOS00ZDE0LTk5ZDMtOWRlNGRmY2U0ODY2&sort=name&layout=list&pid=0B3nMfjn73O0gYzNkZGFiODktYTA4Ny00MTAxLWFkOTgtZDE3OTQ2MDk0ZTYx&cindex=18 ''Canada Remembers Program Policy Manual''], Veterans Affairs Canada, 2009 revision</ref>
Following the installation of the [[Canadian Tomb of the Unknown Soldier|Tomb of the Unknown Soldier]] at the [[National War Memorial (Canada)|National War Memorial]] in [[Ottawa]] in 2000, where the national Remembrance service is held, a new tradition formed spontaneously as attendees laid their poppies on the tomb at the end of the service. This tradition, while not part of the official program, has become widely practised elsewhere in the country, with others leaving cut flowers, photographs, or letters to the dead.
Since joining Canada in 1949, the remembrance poppy and [[Armistice Day]] commemorations have largely displaced [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland's]] own commemorative floral emblem, the [[forget-me-not]], and its own [[Memorial Day (Newfoundland and Labrador)|Memorial Day]] held on 1 July. Although in recent years the forget-me-not has had somewhat of a resurgence in Newfoundland's military commemorations,<ref>http://www.thetelegram.com/News/Local/2016-06-22/article-4567810/Special-Forget-Me-Nots/1 "Special Forget-Me-Nots" {{dead link|date=November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/newfoundland-labrador/forget-me-not-newfoundland-legion-beaumont-hamel-1.3360692|title=Legion members given go-ahead to wear forget-me-nots in 2016 - CBC News|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref> the remembrance poppy is more common.
===New Zealand=== [[File:NZRSA remembrance poppy.jpg|thumb|upright|New Zealand remembrance poppy]]In New Zealand, remembrance poppies are most often worn on Anzac Day (25 April) to commemorate New Zealand soldiers who died in war. They are also worn on Remembrance Day, and are sold by the [[Royal New Zealand Returned and Services' Association]] (RSA) in return for donations. The RSA planned to hold its first Poppy Day appeal around the time of Armistice Day 1921, as other countries were doing. The ship carrying the poppies from France arrived in New Zealand too late, and so the association waited until Anzac Day 1922. This first Poppy Day appeal was a success. Most of the money raised went to needy soldiers and their families, while the rest went to the French Children's League to help relieve suffering in war-ravaged areas of northern France.
The popularity of Poppy Day grew and there were record collections during the Second World War. By 1945, 750,000 poppies were being distributed nationwide, which equated to half the population.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The red poppy - Anzac Day {{!}} NZHistory, New Zealand history online|url = http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/war/anzac-day/poppies|website = www.nzhistory.net.nz|accessdate = 11 November 2015}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== [[File:A volunteer constructs poppies at the Royal British Legion Poppy Factory, Richmond MOD 45148164.jpg|thumb|right|A volunteer makes red remembrance poppies at the Royal British Legion Poppy Factory in London, where over 30 million poppies are made by a small team each year]]
[[File:Bluestar 574.JPG|thumb|A poppy on a bus in [[Southampton]], England (November 2008)]] [[File:Remembrance Poppy an der Manchester Town Hall.JPG|thumb|Big plastic poppy at [[Manchester Town Hall]] (November 2015)]] In the United Kingdom, remembrance poppies are sold by [[The Royal British Legion]] (RBL). This is a [[Charitable organization|charity]] providing financial, social, political and emotional support to those who have served or who are currently serving in the [[British Armed Forces]], and their dependants. They are sold on the streets by volunteers in the weeks before Remembrance Day. The remembrance poppy is the [[trademark]] of The Royal British Legion.<ref name=ipo1>{{cite web|title=EU000681452|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/tmcase/Results/4/EU000681452|website=IPO|publisher=Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=ipo3>{{cite web|title=EU004066271|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/tmcase/Results/4/EU004066271|website=IPO|publisher=Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref><ref name=ipo2>{{cite web|title=EU000681452|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/tmowner/Owner/Results?name=British%20Legion&postcode=|website=IPO|publisher=Intellectual Property Office|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref> The RBL state, "The red poppy is our [[trademark|registered mark]] and its only lawful use is to raise funds for the Poppy Appeal";<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-wiltshire-15654558 "Wiltshire woman's poppy teardrop 'violates trademark'"]. BBC News, 9 November 2011. Retrieved 10 November 2012.</ref> its yearly fundraising drive in the weeks before Remembrance Day. The RBL says these poppies are "worn to commemorate the sacrifices of our Armed Forces and to show support to those still serving today".<ref>[http://www.britishlegion.org.uk/get-involved/poppy-appeal Poppy Appeal 2014 - The Royal British Legion website] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141103033305/http://www.britishlegion.org.uk/get-involved/poppy-appeal |date=3 November 2014 }}. Retrieved 4 November 2014.</ref> Other poppy merchandise is sold throughout the year as part of the ongoing fundraising.<ref name=poppyshop>{{cite web|title=Poppy Shop|url=http://www.poppyshop.org.uk/|website=The Poppy Shop|publisher=RBL|accessdate=13 October 2014}}</ref>
In England, Wales, and Northern Ireland, the poppies typically have two red paper petals mounted on a green plastic stem with a single green paper leaf and a prominent black plastic central boss. The stem has an additional branch used to anchor the poppy via a pin in the lapel or buttonhole. In Scotland, the poppies are curled and have four petals with no leaf. The yearly selling of poppies is a major source of income for the RBL in the UK. The poppy has no fixed price; it is sold for a donation or the price may be suggested by the seller. The black plastic centre of the poppy was marked "[[Haig Fund]]" until 1994 but is now marked "Poppy Appeal".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/index.html |title=White Poppies For Peace |publisher=Ppu.org.uk |date= |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> A team of about 50 people—most of them disabled former British military personnel—work all year round to make millions of poppies at the [[Poppy Factory]] in [[Richmond, London|Richmond]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.poppyfactory.org/|title=The Royal British Legion Poppy Factory|publisher=The Royal British Legion|accessdate=11 November 2009}}</ref> Scottish poppies are made in the [[Lady Haig's Poppy Factory]] in Edinburgh.
For many years after World War I, poppies were worn only on Remembrance Day itself.<ref name="Letters to the Daily Telegraph">{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/comment/letters/3634134/Letters-to-the-Daily-Telegraph.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title=Letters to the Daily Telegraph | date=11 November 2006}}</ref> Today the RBL's "Poppy Appeal" has a higher profile than any other charity appeal in the UK.<ref name="Letters to the Daily Telegraph"/> The poppies are widespread from late October until mid-November every year and are worn by the general public, politicians, the Royal Family and other public figures. It has become common to see large poppies on buses, tube trains and aeroplanes as well as on lampposts, billboards, public buildings and landmarks. Many newspapers and magazines show a poppy on their cover page, and some [[Social network service|social network]] users add poppies to their [[avatar (computing)|avatar]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twibbon.com/join/Royal-British-Legion-2|title=Search for a Campaign - Twibbon|work=Twibbon|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Each year, an official Poppy Appeal [[Single (music)|single]] has been released.<ref name=jossstone>[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/joss-stone-criticised-over-sentimentalising-famed-anti-war-song-for-poppy-appeal-9847312.html "Joss Stone criticised for sentimentalising famed anti-war song for Poppy Appeal"]. [[The Independent]]. 10 November 2014.</ref> There are thousands of poppy sellers on the streets and numerous fundraising events; such as concerts, fairs, marathons and competitions. There are also many other events to raise awareness. For example, in 2011, a Second World War plane dropped 6,000 poppies over the town of [[Yeovil]] in [[Somerset]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-somerset-15507929 "WWII plane drops poppies over Yeovil"]. BBC News. 29 October 2011.</ref> In 2014, the dry [[moat]] of the [[Tower of London]] was [[Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red|covered with 888,246 ceramic poppies]] – one for each soldier of the British Empire killed in World War I.
There has been growing controversy over the Poppy Appeal. Some—including British Army veterans—have argued that the Poppy Appeal has become excessive and garish, that it is being used to marshal support behind British military campaigns, and that poppy wearing has become compulsory for public figures.<ref name=poppyveterans>[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/nov/05/poppy-appeal-subverted-veterans-complain "Poppy appeal's original aims being subverted, veterans complain"]. [[The Guardian]]. 5 November 2010.</ref><ref name=harrysmith>[https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/nov/08/poppy-last-time-remembrance-harry-leslie-smith "This year, I will wear a poppy for the last time"]. [[The Guardian]]. 8 November 2013.</ref> [[Channel 4]] newsreader [[Jon Snow (journalist)|Jon Snow]] described it as "poppy fascism".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1533751/I-wont-bow-to-poppy-fascists-says-Jon-Snow.html|title=I won't bow to poppy fascists, says Jon Snow|last=Pook|first=Sally|date=10 November 2006|publisher=[[Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=5 November 2009 | location=London}}</ref> Columnist Dan O'Neill wrote that "presenters and politicians seem to compete in a race to be first – poppies start sprouting in mid-October while the absence of a poppy is interpreted as absence of concern for the war dead, almost as an unpatriotic act of treachery".<ref name=danoneill1>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/columnists/2011/11/09/dan-o-neill-s-outrage-as-politicians-send-more-to-war-while-they-wear-poppies-91466-29743917/ "Dan O’Neill's outrage as 'politicians send more to war while they wear poppies'"]. Wales Online, 9 November 2011.</ref> Likewise, [[Jonathan Bartley]] of the religious think-tank [[Ekklesia (think tank)|Ekklesia]] said "public figures in Britain are urged, indeed in many cases, required, to wear ... the red poppy, almost as an article of faith. There is a [[political correctness]] about the red poppy".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1533752/A-time-to-remember-but-should-we-wear-a-more-Christian-white-poppy-or-a-PC-red.html |title=A time to remember, but should we wear a more 'Christian' white poppy or a 'PC' red? |last=Petre|first=Jonathan|date=10 November 2006|publisher=[[Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=11 November 2011 |location=London}}</ref> Journalist [[Robert Fisk]] complained that the poppy has become a seasonal "fashion accessory" and that people were "ostentatiously wearing a poppy for social or work-related reasons, to look patriotic when it suited them".<ref>Fisk, Robert. [http://www.independent.ie/opinion/analysis/blood-spilled-in-war-is-now-a-fashion-accessory-2926554.html "Blood spilled in war is now a fashion accessory"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]''. 5 November 2011.</ref>Some [[Far-right politics in the United Kingdom|far-right]] groups have used the poppy as a symbol of militant [[British nationalism]], while some Muslims have begun to reject it as a symbol of Western imperialism.<ref name="fox"/>
In 1997 and again in 2000 the Royal British Legion registered the Poppy under Intellectual Property Rights (1997 Case EU000557058)<ref>75</ref> and Trade Mark (2000 Trade Mark 2239583).<ref>76</ref>
====Northern Ireland====
The Royal British Legion also holds a yearly poppy appeal in [[Northern Ireland]] and in 2009 raised more than £1m.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/breaking-news/uk-ireland/poppy-appeal-in-northern-ireland-breaks-pound1m-barrier-14609389.html#ixzz1EskRCxsA "Poppy Appeal in Northern Ireland breaks £1m barrier"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]''. 23 December 2009.</ref> The wearing of poppies in Northern Ireland is controversial.<ref name="fox"/> It is seen by many as a political symbol<ref name="fox"/><ref name=BT1>{{cite news |url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/thousands-gather-to-remember-war-dead-14555647.html |title=Thousands gather to remember war dead |publisher=Belfast Telegraph |date=7 November 2009}}</ref> and a symbol of [[Britishness]],<ref name="fox"/><ref name=cainsymbols>[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/images/symbols/unionloyal.htm Symbols used in Northern Ireland: Unionist and loyalist symbols]. [[Conflict Archive on the Internet]] (CAIN).</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/25480.stm "Adams apologises for Enniskillen bombing"]. BBC News, 8 November 1997.</ref> representing support for the British Army.<ref name=BT1/> The poppy has long been the preserve of the [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]]/[[Ulster loyalism|loyalist]] community.<ref name="fox"/><ref name=cainsymbols/> Loyalist paramilitaries (such as the [[Ulster Volunteer Force|UVF]] and [[Ulster Defence Association|UDA]]) have also used poppies to commemorate their own members who were killed in [[The Troubles]].<ref>Bort, Eberhard. ''Commemorating Ireland: History, politics, culture''. Irish Academic Press, 2004. p.65</ref>
Most [[Irish nationalism|Irish nationalists]]/[[Irish republicanism|republicans]], and Irish Catholics, choose not to wear poppies;<ref name=BT1/> they regard the Poppy Appeal as supporting soldiers who killed Irish civilians (for example on [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday]]) and who [[Operation Banner#Collusion with loyalist paramilitaries|colluded]] with illegal [[Ulster loyalism#Paramilitary and vigilante groups|loyalist paramilitaries]] (for example the [[Glenanne gang]]) during The Troubles.<ref name="fox"/><ref>[http://www.derryjournal.com/community/columnists/maybe_it_s_time_for_a_green_poppy_instead_1_2117641 "Maybe it's time for a green poppy instead"]. ''[[Derry Journal]]''. 12 November 2007.</ref><ref name="andersonstown">[http://www.belfastmedia.com/news_article.php?ID=2242 "PSNI wearing poppies in West Belfast for political reasons: RFJ"]. ''[[Andersonstown News]]''. 28 October 2008.</ref><ref name="westtyronesf">[http://www.westtyronesinnfein.com/news/15040 "BBC's Poppy Wearing Policy Offensive to Majority of Nationalists and Republicans"]. West Tyrone Sinn Féin. 11 November 2009.</ref><ref name="irishind">[http://www.independent.ie/opinion/letters/lest-we-forget-who-they-honour-1218939.html "Lest we forget who they honour"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]''. 14 November 2007.</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/502290.stm | work=BBC News | title=Westlife poppy backing 'not their decision' | date=2 November 1999}}</ref> Irish nationalist groups, and victims' groups, have urged the BBC to end its policy that all presenters must wear poppies. They argue that it [[Journalism ethics and standards|breaches impartiality]] and point out that political symbols are banned in workplaces in Northern Ireland. They also say that the BBC, as a publicly funded body, should broadly reflect the whole community.<ref name="westtyronesf"/><ref>[http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/bbc-presenters-should-be-banned-from-wearning-poppies-1-7042455 "BBC presenters should be banned from wearning poppies"]. [[The News Letter]]. 1 November 2015.</ref> Likewise, the director of [[Relatives for Justice]] has condemned the wearing of poppies by [[Police Service of Northern Ireland|police officers]] in Catholic neighbourhoods, calling it "repugnant and offensive to the vast majority of people within our community, given the [[Operation Banner#Controversies|role of the British Army]]".<ref name="andersonstown"/> In the ''[[Irish Independent]]'', it was claimed that "substantial amounts" of money raised from selling poppies are used "to build monuments to insane or inane generals or build old boys' clubs for the war elite".<ref name="irishind"/> On Remembrance Day 2010 the [[Social Democratic and Labour Party|SDLP]]’s [[Margaret Ritchie (politician)|Margaret Ritchie]] was the first leader of a nationalist party to wear one.<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/ritchie-poppy-is-act-of-moving-on-15003906.html "Poppy is Act of Moving On"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]''.</ref>
===Republic of Ireland=== During World War I, all of Ireland was part of the United Kingdom and about 200,000 Irishmen fought in the British Army (see [[Ireland and World War I]]). Although the British Army is banned from actively recruiting in the Republic of Ireland,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1954/en/act/pub/0018/print.html |title=Defence Act, 1954 |publisher=Irishstatutebook.ie |date=13 May 1954 |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.anphoblacht.com/news/detail/39792 |title=Taxpayers' money used for British Army recruitment in Limerick |publisher=An Phoblacht |date= |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> a small number of its citizens still enlist.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/north-and-south-of-ireland-fighting-the-taliban-together-13922458.html | title=North and South of Ireland fighting the Taliban together | accessdate=11 May 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Bootcamp Ireland |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/irish-soldier-killed-in-bomb-blast-told-of-afghan-fears-1470617.html |title=Irish soldier killed in bomb blast told of Afghan fears - National News, Frontpage |publisher=Independent.ie |date= 6 September 2008|accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Self-catering |url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/jobs-careers/the-irish-recruits-who-fight-for-queen-and-country-1502910.html |title=The Irish recruits who fight for Queen and country - Jobs & Careers, Lifestyle |publisher=Independent.ie |date= 18 October 2008|accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> The RBL thus has a branch in the Republic and holds a yearly Poppy Appeal there. The RBL also holds a wreath-laying ceremony at [[St Patrick's Cathedral, Dublin]], which the [[President of Ireland]] has attended.<ref>[http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/local/republic_gets_behind_poppy_appeal_1_1873137 "Republic gets behind Poppy Appeal"]. ''[[The News Letter]]''. 29 July 2008.</ref>
The Republic has its own [[National Day of Commemoration]] in July for all Irish people who died in war. As in other non-[[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] countries, poppies are not often worn and are not part of the main commemorations.<ref>[http://www.thejournal.ie/readme/column-is-it-time-to-start-wearing-the-poppy-275814-Nov2011/ Column: Is it time to start wearing the poppy?]. [[TheJournal.ie]]. 10 November 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/government-defend-taoiseach-decision-not-to-wear-poppy-28895378.html "Government defends Taoiseach decision not to wear poppy"]. ''[[Irish Independent]]'', 12 November 2012.</ref> This is partly due to the British Army's role in fighting against Irish independence, its activities during the [[Irish War of Independence|War of Independence]] (for example the [[Burning of Cork]])<ref>[http://www.nga.ie/news-press_release-Wearing_of_the_British_Poppy.php Wearing of the British poppy]. [[National Graves Association]].</ref> and the British Army's role in Northern Ireland during [[the Troubles]].
In the years following the War of Independence, the poppy was particularly controversial, with nationalists seeing it as a provocative symbol of British imperialism. In Dublin, British Legion marchers often had poppies snatched from their lapels, which led to street fights. In response, some poppy-wearers hid razor blades in their poppies.<ref>McGarry, Fearghal. ''Republicanism in Modern Ireland''. University College Dublin Press, 2003. p.66</ref><ref>Martin Evans & Kenneth Lunn. ''War and Memory in the Twentieth Century''. Bloomsbury Academic, 1997. p.66</ref> "As the 1930s progressed, 'Poppy Day' lost much of its violent edge in Dublin, but the wearing of the symbol also became less commonplace in subsequent decades".<ref>[http://comeheretome.com/2015/11/04/poppy-snatching-in-dublin/ "Poppy-snatching in Dublin"]. ''Come Here to Me – Dublin life and culture''. 4 November 2015.</ref>
In 2017, Taoiseach [[Leo Varadkar]] wore a "shamrock poppy" in the [[Dáil]], the first leader of [[Fine Gael]] to do so.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-41910166|title=Irish PM wears 'shamrock poppy'|date=8 November 2017|work=BBC News|access-date=8 November 2017}}</ref>
===Elsewhere=== In the United States, the [[Veterans of Foreign Wars]] conducted the first nationwide distribution of remembrance poppies before [[Memorial Day]] in 1922.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vfw.org/Community/Buddy-Poppy/|title=VFW Buddy Poppy Program - In Flander' s Field Poem by John McCrae|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Today, the [[American Legion Auxiliary]] distributes crepe-paper poppies in exchange for donations around [[Memorial Day]] and [[Veterans Day]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion-aux.org/Programs/Poppy/|title=Login|author=American Legion Auxiliary|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130221092320/http://www.legion-aux.org/Programs/Poppy/|archivedate=21 February 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion.org/troops/216371/legion-family-flower-remembrance|title=Legion Family flower of remembrance|work=The American Legion|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Office of Public and Intergovernmental Affairs |url=http://www1.va.gov/opa/vetsday/vetday_faq.asp |title=Veterans Day Frequently Asked Questions - Office of Public and Intergovernmental Affairs |publisher=.va.gov |date=10 November 2009 |accessdate=23 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228162109/http://www1.va.gov/opa/vetsday/vetday_faq.asp |archivedate=28 February 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legion.org/troops/216371/legion-family-flower-remembrance |title=distribution of poppies is prominent around Memorial Day and Veterans Day |publisher=American Legion |date= |accessdate=3 October 2013}}</ref>
In [[Hong Kong]]—which was formerly part of the British Empire—the poppy is worn by some participants on Remembrance Sunday each year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/topics/remembrance-day|title=Remembrance Day|work=South China Morning Post|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hkesa.com.hk/Events%20&%20Activities.php#remembranceDay|title=HKESA Home Page|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> It is not generally worn by the public, although The Royal British Legion's Hong Kong and China Branch sells poppies to the public in a few places in Hong Kong only.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://branches.britishlegion.org.uk/branches/hong-kong/poppy-appeal|title=The Poppy Appeal in Hong Kong - Hong Kong & China Branch - The Royal British Legion.|publisher=|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref>
[[File:Ніколи Знову 02.svg|thumb|Never Again symbol from [[Ukraine]]]]
Since 2014, the [[Ukraine|Ukrainians]] have worn the poppy as a symbol of the [[Victory Day over Nazism in World War II|Victory over Nazism]] and commemoration of the victims of World War II. It has largely replaced the [[Ribbon of Saint George]], which became associated with [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine|pro-Russian separatists]] and Russian military aggression. A poppy logo was designed by Serhiy Mishakin and contains the text: "1939-1945 Never Again".<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2014/05/14/poppies-vs-ribbons-the-war-of-symbols-between-ukraine-and-russia/ "Poppies Vs. Ribbons: The War Of Symbols Between Ukraine And Russia"]. ''Forbes''. 14 May 2014.</ref>
In parts of [[Pakistan]], the 'Great War Company' hold a private ceremony each 11 November where red poppies are worn, by descendants of World War I veterans from the old [[British Indian Army]].<ref>Asim Ghani, article, 'Auld lang syne?--shall they be never forgotten indeed?', in the ''Pakistan Observer'', Islamabad, Monday, 18 November 2013</ref>
In [[Albania]], government representatives, including Prime Minister [[Edi Rama]], wore the Remembrance Poppy during the commemoration ceremonies for the 70th Anniversary of the Liberation of Albania.<ref>[http://www.shekulli.com.al/web/p.php?id=61467&kat=88 "70-vjetori i Çlirimit/ Krerët e Shtetit, homazhe te Varrezat e Dëshmorëve (FOTO)"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20141215114113/http://www.shekulli.com.al/web/p.php?id=61467&kat=88 |date=15 December 2014 }}. ''Shekulli''. 29 November 2014</ref>
==Other designs and purposes==
===White poppies=== [[File:Anzac poppies.JPG|thumb|A white remembrance poppy left on [[Anzac Day]] in New Zealand, 2009]] Some people choose to wear [[White poppy (symbol)|white poppies]] as an alternative to the red poppy. The white poppy and white poppy wreaths were introduced by Britain's [[Co-operative Women's Guild]] in 1933.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/white_cwg.html |title=White Poppies For Peace |publisher=[[Peace Pledge Union]] |date=11 November 1938 |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> Today, white poppies are sold by [[Peace Pledge Union]] or may be home-made.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/index.html |title=White Poppies Are For Peace |publisher=Peace Pledge Union |date= |accessdate=23 February 2011}}</ref> The white poppy may be worn alone or alongside the red poppy. According to the Peace Pledge Union, it symbolises remembrance of all casualties of war including civilian casualties, and non-British casualties, to stand for peace, and not to glamorize war.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ppu.org.uk/whitepoppy/index.html|title=WHITE POPPIES|website=www.ppu.org.uk|accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref> While it was never meant to be disrespectful, some people were very offended with the use of the white poppy and some women in the 1930s lost their jobs for wearing white poppies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/remembrance/how/poppy.shtml|title=BBC - Remembrance - Why the Poppy?|publisher=|accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref>
=== Purple poppies === {{more|Purple poppy}} To commemorate animal victims of war, [[Animal Aid]] in Britain has issued a [[purple poppy|purple remembrance poppy]], which can be worn alongside the traditional red one, as a reminder that both humans and animals have been – and continue to be – victims of war.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animalaid.org.uk/h/n/CAMPAIGNS/living//2256/|title=BLUE POPPY: COMMEMORATING THE ANIMAL VICTIMS OF WAR|accessdate=31 October 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130121070658/http://www.animalaid.org.uk/h/n/CAMPAIGNS/living//2256//|archivedate=21 January 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/8333733.stm|title= The dos and don'ts of poppy etiquette|publisher=BBC|accessdate=28 October 2013|date=30 October 2009}}</ref> Recently, the purple poppy was replaced by a purple paw symbol that can be worn all year round. This was because people saw the poppy as implying animals had given their lives as heroes in the service of human beings. Animal Aid regards animals of having their lives taken by the abuse of humans in war, not given by the animals as could be the case with people who have the capacity to decide for themselves.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.animalaid.org.uk/the-issues/our-campaigns/living-without-cruelty/the-purple-poppy/|title=Animal Aid|publisher=|accessdate=5 May 2017}}</ref>
On 11 April 2017 a UK based animal charity [[Sasha Animal Foundation]] announced that it was to introduce its own blue poppy with a different design, stating: "We will be adhering to the stance that animals are victims of war and not heroes".<ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://www.SashaAnimalFoundation.com|title=Sasha Animal Foundation Home|website=Sasha Animal Foundation Home|access-date=5 May 2017}}</ref>
=== Black poppies === On Remembrance Sunday 1999 a Merseyside group protesting against sanctions and war on Iraq laid a wreath of black poppies on the cenotaph in Liverpool <ref>["Military veterans refuse mayor's salute"]. ''[[Morning Star (British newspaper)]]''. 15 November 1999.</ref>. In 2014 the black poppy was embraced as an anti war symbol by the [[Stop the War Coalition]] which reported 'anti militarists' in Glasgow distributing 16,000 black poppies in memory of World War One conscientious objectors <ref>{{Citeweb|url=http://www.stopwar.org.uk/index.php/news-comment/1131-why-no-remembrance-day-black-poppies-for-16-000-first-world-war-refusers|title=Why No Remembrance Day black poppies For 16,000 First World War Refusers|website=[[Stop the War Coalition]]|access-date=6 November 2018}}</ref>
==Protests and controversy== [[File:Stormtrooper with a remembrance poppy - stencil (2016).jpg|thumb|upright|[[Stencil graffiti]] of a [[Stormtrooper (Star Wars)|Stormtrooper]] with a remembrance poppy (London, 2016)]] In 1993, The Royal British Legion complained that ''[[Cannon Fodder (video game)|Cannon Fodder]]'', a video game with an anti-war message, had planned to use a poppy on its cover. The Legion, along with some politicians, called it "offensive to millions" and "monstrous". The publisher was forced to change the cover before the game was released.
In 2010 a group of British Army veterans issued an open letter complaining that the Poppy Appeal had become excessive and garish, that it was being used to marshal support behind British military campaigns, and that people were being pressured into wearing poppies.<ref name=poppyveterans/> In 2014, the group protested by holding an alternative remembrance service: they walked to [[The Cenotaph, Whitehall|The Cenotaph]] under the banner "Never Again" with a wreath of white poppies to acknowledge civilians killed in war. Their tops bore the message "War is Organised Murder", a quote from [[Harry Patch]], the last survivor of World War I.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/never-again-anti-war-veterans-to-carry-white-poppy-wreath-to-cenotaph-9833246.html "'Never again': Anti-war veterans to carry white-poppy wreath to Cenotaph"]. [[The Independent]]. 2 November 2014.</ref><ref>[http://veteransforpeace.org.uk/2014/war-weary-veterans-hold-aternative-remembrance-sunday-event/ "War-Weary Veterans Hold Alternative Remembrance Sunday Event"]. Veterans For Peace. 11 November 2014.</ref>
A 2010 Remembrance Day ceremony in London was disrupted by members of the radical Islamist [[Muslims Against Crusades]] group, who were protesting against British Army actions in Afghanistan and Iraq. They burnt large poppies and chanted "British soldiers burn in hell" during the two-minute silence. Two of the men were arrested and charged for threatening behaviour. One was convicted and fined £50.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-12664346 "Man guilty of burning poppies at Armistice Day protest"]. BBC News. 7 March 2011.</ref> The same group planned to hold another protest in 2011,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/user/izharudeen#p/a/u/0/sJg9wHsEiEU |title=Interview with convicted terrorist Abu Izzadeen about 'Hell for Heroes' protests |date=1 November 2011 |publisher=Izharudeen.com |accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref> but was banned by the [[Home Secretary]] the day before the planned protest.<ref>{{cite news|last=Casciani|first=Dominic|title=Muslims Against Crusades banned by Theresa May|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15678275|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=11 November 2011|date=10 November 2011}}</ref> In 2014, a campaign was begun to encourage Muslim women to wear poppy [[hijab]]s. Some criticised it as a "shrouded loyalty test" which implied that Muslims needed to prove their loyalty to Britain.<ref>Allen, Chris. [http://www.newstatesman.com/politics/2014/11/poppy-hijab-just-islamophobia-floral-motif "The poppy hijab is just Islamophobia with a floral motif"]. [[New Statesman]]. 3 November 2014.</ref><ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2014/11/split-uk-opinion-over-poppy-hijabs-20141196523894487.html "Split UK opinion over 'poppy hijabs'"]. [[Al Jazeera]]. 9 November 2014.</ref><ref>[http://edition.cnn.com/2014/10/31/world/europe/poppy-hijab-controversy/ "Poppy hijab honors Muslims, sparks controversy"]. CNN. 1 November 2014.</ref>
In November 2011 people were arrested in Northern Ireland after a picture of two youths burning a poppy was posted on [[Facebook]]. The picture was reported to police by a member of the RBL.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2011/nov/03/poppy-burning-northern-ireland-arrests?newsfeed=true | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Henry | last=McDonald | title=Poppy-burning image leads to Northern Ireland arrests | date=3 November 2011}}</ref> The following year, a young [[Canterbury]] man was arrested for allegedly posting a picture of a burning poppy on Facebook, on suspicion of an offence under the Malicious Communications Act.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rawlinson|first=Kevin|title='Poppycock': Man's arrest for posting image of burning poppy on Facebook is condemned by civil liberties activists|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/poppycock-mans-arrest-for-posting-image-of-burning-poppy-on-facebook-is-condemned-by-civil-liberties-activists-8306784.html|publisher=Independent.co.uk|accessdate=4 February 2013|location=London|date=12 November 2012}}</ref>
British Prime Minister David Cameron rejected a request from Chinese officials to remove his poppy during his visit to [[Beijing]] on Remembrance Day 2010. The poppy was deemed offensive because it was mistakenly assumed to be connected with the Anglo-Chinese [[Opium Wars]] of the 19th century, after which the [[Qing Dynasty]] was forced to tolerate the British [[History of opium in China|opium trade]] in China and to cede [[Hong Kong]] to the UK.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-09/cameron-risks-spat-with-chinese-by-wearing-poppy-during-visit-to-beijing.html|title=Cameron Risks Spat With Chinese by Wearing Poppy During Visit |date=9 November 2010 |publisher=Bloomberg LP |accessdate=12 November 2011 |first=Robert |last=Hutton}}</ref>
In 2012 there was controversy when [[The Northern Whig]] public house in [[Belfast]] refused entry to a man wearing a remembrance poppy.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20208930 | title=Northern Whig bar apologises after poppy-wearer refused entry | year= 2012 | publisher= BBC News | accessdate=12 March 2015 }}</ref> Although the owners apologised, the customer took the matter to court, supported by the [[Equality Commission for Northern Ireland]] (ECNI).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.equalityni.org/Footer-Links/News/Individuals/Sample-headline-text-(3) | title=Refusal of man wearing poppy | year= 2013 | publisher= Equality Commission for Northern Ireland | accessdate=5 August 2017 }}</ref> The case was significant for the decision supporting the view of the ECNI that "The poppy, although not directly linked to a specific religious belief or political opinion, would historically have been associated to a greater extent with the Protestant or unionist community in Northern Ireland".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.irishnews.com/news/2013/11/27/news/poppy-refusal-discrimination-76888/ | title=Poppy refusal discrimination | year= 2013 | publisher= The Irish News | accessdate=5 August 2017 }}</ref>
===In the media=== In the British media, public figures have been attacked for not wearing poppies. British journalist and newsreader [[Charlene White]] has faced racist and sexist abuse for not wearing a poppy on-screen. She explained "I prefer to be neutral and impartial on screen so that one of those charities doesn't feel less favoured than another".<ref>Shane Hickey [https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2013/nov/13/charlene-white-itv-news-presenter-remembrance-day-poppy "ITV news presenter hits back after abuse for not wearing poppy"], theguardian.com, 13 November 2013</ref> Newsreader [[Jon Snow (journalist)|Jon Snow]] does not wear a poppy on-screen for similar reasons. He too was criticised and he condemned what he saw as "poppy fascism".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/newsreader-jon-snow-rails-against-poppy-fascism-7263001.html|title=Newsreader Jon Snow rails against 'poppy fascism'|date=9 November 2006|work=Evening Standard|accessdate=20 May 2016}}</ref> Well-known war-time journalist [[Robert Fisk]] published in November 2011 a personal account about the shifting nature of wearing a poppy, titled "Do those who flaunt the poppy on their lapels know that they mock the war dead?".<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-do-those-who-flaunt-the-poppy-on-their-lapels-know-that-they-mock-the-war-dead-6257416.html "Do those who flaunt the poppy on their lapels know that they mock the war dead?"]. [[The Independent]]. Accessed 4 November 2014.</ref> While all newsreaders in the UK are expected to wear the remembrance poppy, those on the [[BBC World News|BBC's international news]] service are told not to. The BBC say this is because the symbol is not widely recognised overseas. The Royal British Legion condemned this, insisting that the poppy is the "international symbol of remembrance".<ref>[http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/mp-s-fury-at-bbc-ban-on-poppies-1-584905 "MP’s fury at BBC ban on poppies"]. ''The Scotsman''. 3 November 2001.</ref>
===In sport=== [[File:Celtic team - November 2010.jpg|thumb|right|Football clubs commonly wear jerseys with a poppy emblazoned on, as [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] controversially did in 2010.]] In the run-up to Remembrance Day, it has become common for UK [[Association football|football]] teams to play with artificial poppies sewn to their shirts, at the request of the Royal British Legion. This has caused some controversy.
At a [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] v [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] match in November 2010, a group of Celtic supporters, called the [[Green Brigade]], unfurled a large banner in protest at the team wearing poppies. In a statement, it said: "Our group and many within the Celtic support do not recognise the British Armed Forces as heroes, nor their role in many conflicts as one worthy of our remembrance". It gave [[Operation Banner]] (Northern Ireland), the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]] and the [[Iraq War]] as examples.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.etims.net/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=3038&Itemid=29 |title=Green Brigade Statement on the Poppy Protest |date=9 November 2010 |publisher=E-Tims Online Fanzine |accessdate=5 January 2011}}</ref>
Northern Irish-born footballer [[James McClean]], who has played for several English teams, has received [[death threat]]s and abuse since 2012 for refusing to wear a poppy on his shirt during matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/nov/18/sunderland-james-mcclean-death-threat|title=Sunderland's James McClean receives death threat over poppy protest|first=Dominic|last=Fifield|date=18 November 2012|website=the Guardian|accessdate=28 October 2018}}</ref> McClean said he does not wear one because the Poppy Appeal supports British soldiers who served in Northern Ireland, and believes it would disrespect those killed in [[Derry|his hometown]] on [[Bloody Sunday (1972)|Bloody Sunday]].<ref>[http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/wigan-player-james-mcclean-explains-why-he-will-not-wear-a-poppy-30730556.html "Wigan player James McClean explains why he will not wear a poppy"]. ''Belfast Telegraph''. 10 November 2014.</ref>
In November 2011, it was proposed that the [[England national football team|England football team]] should wear poppies on their shirts in a match against [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. [[FIFA]] turned down the proposal; their decision was attacked by [[Prince William, Duke of Cambridge|Prince William]]<ref name=guardian-fifa-2011>[https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/nov/09/david-cameron-outrageous-poppy-ban?newsfeed=true "Prince William calls on FIFA to overturn ban on England shirt poppies"]. ''[[The Guardian]]'', 9 November 2011.</ref> FIFA subsequently allowed the English, Scottish and Welsh teams to wear poppies on black armbands.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15666769.stm "FIFA allows England, Scotland and Wales to wear poppy"], [[BBC News]], 9 November 2011. Accessed 12 November 2011.</ref>
On 11 November 2017, the third day of the [[Women's Test]] match held at [[North Sydney Oval]] as part of the [[English women's cricket team in Australia in 2017–18|Women's Ashes 2017–18]], both the Australian and the English team players wore poppies to mark 99 years since the end of World War I.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Collins |first1=Adam |last2=Ehantharajah |first2=Vithushan |title=Ellyse Perry scores 213 for Australia on day three of Women's Ashes Test match – as it happened |url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/live/2017/nov/11/australia-v-england-womens-ashes-test-match-day-three-live?page=with:block-5a067dfb437a7d06e9058660 |accessdate=11 November 2018 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=11 November 2017}}</ref>
During the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|2018 FIFA World Cup Qualifiers]], the England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland football teams were fined for displaying the poppy during matches. FIFA rules forbid the display of "political or religious symbols".<ref name="IndependentDec2016">{{cite news|last1=de Menezes|first1=Jack|title=England just got fined £35,000 for defying Fifa's poppy ban|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/fifa-poppy-ban-england-fine-35000-scotland-a7484296.html|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=The Independent|date=19 December 2016}}</ref><ref name="Independent23Nov2016">{{cite news|last1=de Menezes|first1=Jack|title=Fifa take action against Wales because 'fans were wearing poppies'|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/international/fifa-poppy-ban-northern-ireland-wales-england-scotland-poppies-a7433511.html|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=The Independent|date=23 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph19Dec2016">{{cite news|last1=Law|first1=Matt|title=FA could take Fifa to Court of Arbitration for Sport over £35,000 fine for poppy use|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/12/19/fifa-fine-football-associations-england-scotland-northern-ireland/|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=19 December 2016}}</ref> The decision was strongly criticised by Prime Minister [[Theresa May]], and the Welsh and English football associations appealed against the fine, with the English Football Association threatening to bring the matter to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]].<ref name="Telegraph19Dec2016" /><ref name="EurosportNov2016">{{cite news|title=England and Scotland to defy FIFA poppy ban|url=http://www.eurosport.com/football/world-cup-qualification-caf/2018/england-and-scotland-to-defy-fifa-poppy-ban_sto5937190/story.shtml|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=Eurosport|date=2 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="WalesOnline">{{cite news|last1=Abbandonato|first1=Paul|title=Wales appeal against FIFA fine over poppies|url=http://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/wales-launch-appeal-over-fifas-12585392|accessdate=26 July 2017|work=Wales Online|date=10 February 2017}}</ref>
In November 2018, Manchester United's Serbian midfielder [[Nemanja Matić]] refused to wear a poppy on his shirt for a match against Bournemouth.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46099843 |title=Nemanja Matic: Man Utd midfielder explains why he will not wear poppy |date=5 November 2018 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref> After the match, Matić was castigated and got threats by a number of people via social networks for not respecting servicemen who have died in war.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/memory-of-bombing-raid-is-why-ive-stopped-wearing-poppy-says-matic-zqch809b3 |title=Memory of bombing raid is why I’ve stopped wearing poppy |date=5 November 2018 |publisher=The Times |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref> Matić stated that he will not wear a poppy because his village of [[Vrelo (Ub)|Vrelo]] was hit by the [[NATO bombing of Yugoslavia]] in 1999.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46099843 |title=Nemanja Matic: Man Utd midfielder explains why he will not wear poppy |date=5 November 2018 |publisher=BBC |accessdate=5 November 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[The Red Poppies on Monte Cassino]] – in Polish tradition poppies are used as a remembrance symbol of the [[Battle of Monte Cassino]]. * [[Bleuet de France]] – the cornflower of France, the French equivalent of the remembrance poppy. * [[Blood Swept Lands and Seas of Red]] – a work of installation art placed in the moat of the Tower of London.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/world/2014/11/10/why_not_all_poppies_look_the_same.html|title=Why not all poppies look the same|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=10 November 2014|accessdate=10 November 2017}} * {{cite news|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2014/11/10/poppy_protocol_six_rules_you_need_to_follow.html|title=Poppy protocol: six rules you need to follow|last=Edwards|first=Peter|newspaper=Toronto Star|date=10 November 2014|accessdate=10 November 2017}}

revision.comment: link [[economic interventionism|government intervention]] using [[:en:User:Edward/Find link|Find link]]
revision.text:
'''Renewable heat''' is an application of [[renewable energy]] and it refers to the renewable generation of heat, rather than electrical power (e.g. replacing a fossil fuel boiler using [[concentrating solar thermal]] to feed radiators). Renewable heat technologies include renewable biofuels, solar heating, geothermal heating, heat pumps and heat exchangers to recover lost heat. Significant attention is also applied to insulation. Many colder countries consume more energy for heating than electrical power. For example, in 2005 the United Kingdom consumed 354 TWhDepartment of Trade and Industry report [http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file39881.pdf UK Energy in Brief July 2007, Page 25] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527233923/http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file39881.pdf |date=May 27, 2008 }} (URL accessed May, 2008) of electric power, but had a heat requirement of 907 TWh, the majority of which (81%) was met using gas. The residential sector alone consumed a massive 550 TWh of energy for heating, mainly in the form of gas. Almost half of the final energy consumed in the UK (49%) was in the form of heat, of which 70% was used by households and in commercial and public buildings. Households used heat mainly for space heating (69%) and heating water.UK Government Call for Evidence on Heat, Office of Climate Change, Jan 2008 [http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file43609.pdf 'Heat Call for Evidence', Paragraphs 11 and 12] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080527233914/http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file43609.pdf |date=May 27, 2008 }} (URL accessed May, 2008) The relative competitiveness of renewable electricity and renewable heat depends on a nation's approach to energy and environment policy. Few renewable technologies (whether for heat, electricity or transport) are competitive with fossil fuels without some form of carbon valuation or subsidy. In those countries, such as Sweden, Denmark and Finland, where [[government intervention]] has been closest to a technology-neutral form of carbon valuation (i.e. carbon and [[energy tax]]es), renewable heat has played the leading role in a very substantial renewable contribution to final energy consumption. In those countries, such as Germany, Spain, the USA, and the UK, where government intervention has been set at different levels for different technologies, uses and scales, the contributions of renewable heat and renewable electricity technologies have depended on the relative levels of support, and have resulted generally in a lower renewable contribution to final energy consumption. == Leading renewable heat technologies == === Solar heating === [[Solar heating]] is a style of building construction which uses the energy of summer or winter sunshine to provide an economic supply of primary or supplementary heat to a structure. The heat can be used for both [[space heating]] (see [[solar air heat]]) and [[water heating]] (see [[solar hot water]]). Solar heating design is divided into two groups: * [[Passive solar]] heating relies on the design and structure of the house to collect heat. [[Passive solar building design]] must also consider the storage and distribution of heat, which may be accomplished passively, or use air ducting to draw heat actively to the foundation of the building for storage. One such design was measured lifting the temperature of a house to {{convert|24|C|F}} on a partially sunny winter day (-7 °C or 19 °F), and it is claimed that the system provides passively for the bulk of the building's heating.{{cite web|url=http://www.solarhouseproject.com/index.html |title=Solar House, Solar Home, Solar Homes, Solar Houses |publisher=Solarhouseproject.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-02}} The {{convert|4000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} home cost $125 per square foot (or 370 m2 at $1,351/m2), similar to the cost of a traditional new home. * [[Active solar]] heating uses [[pump]]s to move air or a liquid from the [[Solar thermal collector|solar collector]] into the building or storage area. Applications such as [[solar air heat]]ing and [[solar water heating]] typically capture solar heat in panels which can then be used for applications such as space heating and supplementation of residential water heaters. In contrast to [[photovoltaic panels]], which are used to generate electricity, solar heating panels are less expensive and capture a much higher proportion of the sun's energy. Solar heating systems usually require a small supplementary backup heating system, either conventional or renewable. === Geothermal heating === [[File:Hot Spring.jpg|thumb|right|Hot Springs located in Nevada.]] [[Geothermal energy]] is accessed by drilling water or steam wells in a process similar to drilling for oil. Geothermal energy is an enormous, underused heat and power resource that is clean (emits little or no greenhouse gases), reliable (average system availability of 95%), and homegrown (making populations less dependent on oil).{{cite web|url=http://www1.eere.energy.gov/geothermal/geothermal_basics.html|title=Geothermal Basics Overview|publisher=Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy|accessdate=2009-06-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081004020606/http://www1.eere.energy.gov/geothermal/geothermal_basics.html|archivedate=2008-10-04|df=}} The earth absorbs the sun's energy and stores it as heat in the oceans and underground. The ground temperature remains constant at a point of {{convert|42|to|100|F|C}} all year round depending on where you live on earth. A geothermal heating system takes advantage of the consistent temperature found below the Earth's surface and uses it to heat and cool buildings. The system is made up of a series of pipes installed underground, connected to pipes in a building. A pump circulates liquid through the circuit. In the winter the fluid in the pipe absorbs the heat of the earth and uses it to heat the building. In the summer the fluid absorbs heat from the building and disposes of it in the earth.{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.geothermal.org/what.html |title=What is Geothermal? - Geothermal Resources Council |publisher=Geothermal.org |date=2013-01-22 |accessdate=2013-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005004048/http://www.geothermal.org/what.html |archivedate=2013-10-05 |df= }} ===Heat pumps=== [[Heat pump]]s use work to move heat from one place to another, and can be used for both heating and air conditioning. Though capital intensive, heat pumps are economical to run and can be powered by renewable electricity. Two common types of heat pump are [[air-source heat pump]]s (ASHP) and [[ground-source heat pump]]s (GSHP), depending on whether heat is transferred from the air or from the ground. Air source heat pumps are not effective when the outside air temperature is lower than about -15 °C, while ground-source heat pumps are not affected. The efficiency of a heat pump is measured by the [[coefficient of performance]] (CoP): For every unit of electricity used to pump the heat, an air source heat pump generates 2.5 to 3 units of heat (i.e. it has a CoP of 2.5 to 3), whereas a GSHP generates 3 to 3.5 units of heat. Based on current fuel prices for the United Kingdom, assuming a CoP of 3-4, a GSHP is sometimes a cheaper form of space heating than electric, oil, and solid fuel heating.[http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/renewable-energy/heat/ground-source-heat-pumps Ground Source Heat Pumps: Costs, savings and financial support] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161202165420/http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/renewable-energy/heat/ground-source-heat-pumps |date=December 2, 2016 }} Retrieved 2016-12-02 Heat pumps can be linked to an inter[[seasonal thermal energy storage]] (hot or cold), doubling the CoP from 4 to 8 by extracting heat from warmer ground.{{cite web|url=http://www.icax.co.uk/gshp.html |title=GSHP | Ground Source Heat Pumps | GSHPs | Ground Source Heating | Coefficient of Performance CoP | Ground source heat pump efficiency | Thermal Energy Storage |publisher=Icax.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-10-02}} ====Interseasonal heat transfer==== {{Main|Seasonal thermal energy storage}} A heat pump with Interseasonal Heat Transfer combines active solar collection to store surplus summer heat in thermal banks{{cite web|url=http://www.icax.co.uk/thermalbank.html |title=Thermal Banks store heat between seasons | Seasonal Heat Storage | ThermalBanks from ICAX save carbon emissions | Thermal Energy Storage using Inter seasonal Heat Stores | Underground Thermal Energy Storage UTES | Reusable Heat |publisher=Icax.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-10-02}} with ground-source heat pumps to extract it for space heating in winter. This reduces the "Lift" needed and doubles the CoP of the heat pump because the pump starts with warmth from the thermal bank in place of cold from the ground. ====CoP and lift==== A heat pump CoP increases as the temperature difference, or "Lift", decreases between heat source and destination. The CoP can be maximized at design time by choosing a heating system requiring only a low final water temperature (e.g., underfloor heating), and by choosing a heat source with a high average temperature (e.g., the ground). Domestic hot water (DHW) and conventional radiators require high water temperatures, affecting the choice of heat pump technology. Low temperature radiators provide an alternative to conventional radiators. {| class="wikitable" |- style="font-weight:bold; text-align:center;" ! style="width:160px;" rowspan="2"| Pump type and source ! style="width:110px;" rowspan="2"| Typical use case ! colspan="6" | Heat Pump CoP variation with Output Temperature |- style="font-weight:bold; text-align:center;" ! 35 °C
(e.g. heated screed floor) ! 45 °C

Steen, Table 3.1, Table 3.3] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090318233012/http://www.r744.com/knowledge/papers/files/pdf/pdf_379.pdf |date=2009-03-18 }}. . color:#f00;"| 4.2 | style="text-align:center;"| - | style="text-align:center;"| 3.0 |- | style="height:15px;"| GSHP water at 0 °C | |   | style="text-align:center;"| 5.0 | style="text-align:center;"| 3.7 | style="text-align:center;"| 2.9 | style="text-align:center;"| 2.4 | style="text-align:center;"| - | style="text-align:center;"| - |- | style="height:30px;"| GSHP ground at 10 °C | | Low output temp. | style="text-align:center; text-decoration:underline; color:#f00;"| 7.2 | style="text-align:center;"| 5.0 | style="text-align:center;"| 3.7 | style="text-align:center;"| 2.9 | style="text-align:center;"| 2.4 | style="text-align:center;"| - |- | style="height:15px;"| Theoretical [[Carnot cycle]] limit, source -20 °C | |   | style="text-align:center;"| 5.6 | style="text-align:center;"| 4.9 | style="text-align:center;"| 4.4 | style="text-align:center;"| 4.0 | style="text-align:center;"| 3.7 | style="text-align:center;"| 3.4 |- | style="height:15px;"| Theoretical Carnot cycle limit, source 0 °C | |   | style="text-align:center;"| 8.8 | style="text-align:center;"| 7.1 | style="text-align:center;"| 6.0 | style="text-align:center;"| 5.2 | style="text-align:center;"| 4.6 | style="text-align:center;"| 4.2 |- | style="height:30px;"| Theoretical Lorentz Cycle limit ({{chem|CO|2}} pump), return fluid 25 °C, source 0 °C ||   | style="text-align:center;"| 10.1 | style="text-align:center;"| 8.8 | style="text-align:center;"| 7.9 | style="text-align:center;"| 7.1 | style="text-align:center;"| 6.5 | style="text-align:center;"| 6.1 |- | style="height:15px;"| Theoretical Carnot cycle limit, source 10 °C | |   | style="text-align:center;"| 12.3 | style="text-align:center;"| 9.1 | style="text-align:center;"| 7.3 | style="text-align:center;"| 6.1 | style="text-align:center;"| 5.4 | style="text-align:center;"| 4.8 |} ===Resistive electrical heating=== Renewable electricity can be generated by hydropower, solar, wind, geothermal and by burning biomass. In a few countries where renewable electricity is inexpensive, [[Electric heating|resistance heating]] is common. In countries like Denmark where electricity is expensive, it is not permitted to install electric heating as the main heat source.http://www.seas.columbia.edu/earth/wtert/sofos/DEA_Heat_supply_in_denmark.pdf Wind turbines have more output at night when there is a small demand for electricity, [[storage heater]]s consume this lower cost electricity at night and give off heat during the day. === Wood-pellet heating === [[File:Lincoln stove.jpg|thumb|right|Wood Stove.]][[File:Pellets hand.jpg|thumb|right|Wood Pellets.]] [[Wood-pellet heating]] and other types of wood heating systems have achieved their greatest success in heating premises that are off the gas grid, typically being previously heated using heating oil or coal. Solid wood fuel requires a large amount of dedicated storage space, and the specialized heating systems can be expensive (though grant schemes are available in many European countries to offset this capital cost.) Low fuel costs mean that wood fuelled heating in Europe is frequently able to achieve a payback period of less than 3 to 5 years. Because of the large fuel storage requirement wood fuel can be less attractive in urban residential scenarios, or for premises connected to the gas grid (though rising gas prices and uncertainty of supply mean that wood fuel is becoming more competitive.) There is also growing concern over the air pollution from wood heating versus oil or gas heat, especially the fine particulates. === Wood-stove heating === Burning [[wood fuel]] in an open fire is both extremely inefficient (0-20%) and polluting due to low temperature partial combustion. In the same way that a drafty building loses heat through loss of warm air through poor sealing, an open fire is responsible for large heat losses by drawing very large volumes of warm air out of the building. Modern wood [[stove]] designs allow for more efficient combustion and then heat extraction. In the United States, new wood stoves are certified by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|U.S. Environmental Protection Agency]] (EPA) and burn cleaner and more efficiently (the overall efficiency is 60-80%){{cite web|url=http://epa.gov/bns/reports/stakejun2008/B%28a%29P/WoodstoveFacsheet_08.pdf|title=Burn clean: Hot tips for a better fire|publisher=Environmental Protection Agency}} and draw smaller volumes of warm air from the building. "Cleaner" should not, however, be confused with clean. An Australian study of real-life emissions from woodheaters satisfying the current Australian standard,{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/atmosphere/airquality/publications/emission-factor.html |title=Measurement of real-world PM10 emission factors and emission profiles from woodheaters by in situ source monitoring and atmospheric verification methods |publisher=Environment.gov.au |date=2009-09-16 |accessdate=2013-10-02}} found that particle emissions averaged 9.4 g/kg wood burned (range 2.6 to 21.7). A heater with average wood consumption of 4 tonnes per year therefore emits 37.6 kg of PM2.5, i.e. particles less than 2.5 [[micrometre|micrometers]]. This can be compared with a passenger car satisfying the current [[European emission standards|Euro 5 standards]] (introduced September 2009) of 0.005 g/km. So one new wood heater emits as much PM2.5 per year as 367 passenger cars each driving 20,000 km a year. A recent European study{{cite web |url=http://air-climate.eionet.europa.eu/reports/ETCACC_TP_2009_1_European_PM2.5_HIA |title=Assessment of the health impacts of exposure to PM2.5 at a European levelETC/ACC Technical Paper 2009/1 |publisher=Air-climate.eionet.europa.eu |date=2009-06-29 |accessdate=2013-10-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722210417/http://air-climate.eionet.europa.eu/reports/ETCACC_TP_2009_1_European_PM2.5_HIA |archivedate=2010-07-22 |df= }} identified PM2.5 as the most health-hazardous air pollutant, causing an estimated 492,000 premature deaths. The next worst pollutant, ozone, is responsible for 21,000 premature deaths. Because of the problems with pollution, the Australian Lung Foundation recommends using alternative means for climate control.[http://lungfoundation.com.au/consultation-looks-at-reducing-emissions-from-wood-heaters/]{date=2014-06-01} The American Lung Association "strongly recommends using cleaner, less toxic sources of heat. Converting a wood-burning fireplace or stove to use either natural gas or propane will eliminate exposure to the dangerous toxins wood burning generates including dioxin, arsenic and formaldehyde.{{cite web|url=http://www.lungusa.org/press-room/press-releases/cleaner-alternatives-for-winter-heat.html |title=American Lung Association Cautions Against Wood-burning and Urges Cleaner Alternatives for Winter Heat - American Lung Association |publisher=Lungusa.org |date=2008-09-29 |accessdate=2013-10-02}} "Renewable" should not be confused with "greenhouse neutral". A recent peer-reviewed paper found that, even if burning firewood from a sustainable supply, [[methane emissions]] from a typical Australian wood heater satisfying the current standard cause more global warming than heating the same house with gas. However, because a large proportion of firewood sold in Australia is not from sustainable supplies, Australian households that use wood heating often cause more global warming than heating three similar homes with gas."Australian wood heaters currently increase global warming and health costs", Dorothy L. Robinson, Atmospheric Poolution Research, Article in Press, {{doi|10.5094/APR.2011.033}} High efficiency stoves should meet the following design criteria: * Well sealed and precisely calibrated to draw a low yet sufficient volume of air. Air-flow restriction is critical; a lower inflow of cold air cools the furnace less (a higher temperature is thus achieved). It also allows greater time for extraction of heat from the [[exhaust gas]], and draws less heat from the building. * The furnace must be well insulated to increase combustion temperature, and thus completeness. * A well insulated furnace radiates little heat. Thus heat must be extracted instead from the exhaust gas duct. Heat absorption efficiencies are higher when the heat-exchange duct is longer, and when the flow of exhaust gas is slower. * In many designs, the heat-exchange duct is built of a very large mass of heat-absorbing brick or stone. This design causes the absorbed heat to be emitted over a longer period - typically a day. ===Renewable natural gas=== [[Renewable natural gas]] is defined as gas obtained from [[biomass]] which is upgraded to a quality similar to [[natural gas]].{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} By upgrading the quality to that of natural gas, it becomes possible to distribute the gas to customers via the existing gas grid.{{cite web|url=http://www.dgc.dk/publikationer/konference/jkj_sustain_gas.pdf|publisher=Dgc.dk|title='Sustainable Gas Enters the European Gas Distribution System'|accessdate=2013-10-02}} According to the Energy research Centre of the Netherlands, renewable natural gas is 'cheaper than alternatives where biomass is used in a combined heat and power plant or local combustion plant'.Energy research Centre of the Netherlands [http://www.ecn.nl/docs/library/report/2005/rx05187.pdf 'Heat from Biomass via Synthetic Natural Gas'] . Retrieved March 22, 2006. Energy unit costs are lowered through 'favourable scale and operating hours', and end-user capital costs eliminated through distribution via the existing gas grid. ==Energy efficiency== Renewable heat goes hand in hand with energy efficiency. Indeed, renewable heating projects depend heavily for their success on energy efficiency; in the case of solar heating to cut reliance on the requirement supplementary heating, in the case of wood fuel heating to cut the cost of wood purchased and volume stored, and in the case of heat pumps to reduce the size and investment in heat pump, heat sink and electricity costs. Two main types of improvement can be made to a building's energy efficiency: ===Insulation=== Improvements to insulation can cut energy consumption greatly, making a space cheaper to heat and to cool. However existing housing can often be difficult or expensive to improve. Newer buildings can benefit from many of the techniques of [[superinsulation]]. Older buildings can benefit from several kinds of improvement: * '''Solid wall insulation''': A building with solid walls can benefit from internal or external insulation. External wall insulation involves adding decorative weather-proof insulating panels or other treatment to the outside of the wall. Alternatively, internal wall insulation can be applied using ready-made insulation/plaster board laminates, or other methods. Thicknesses of internal or external insulation typically range between 50 and 100 mm. * '''Cavity wall insulation''': A building with cavity walls can benefit from insulation pumped into the cavity. This form of insulation is very cost effective{{Clarify|date=February 2009}}{{Citation needed|date=July 2008}}. * '''[[Programmable thermostat]]s''' allow heating and cooling of a room to be switched off depending the time, day of the week, and temperature. A bedroom, for example, does not need to be heated during the day, but a living room does not need to be heated during the night. * '''Roof insulation''' * '''Insulated windows and doors''' * '''Draught proofing''' === Underfloor heating === [[Underfloor heating]] may sometimes be more energy efficient than traditional methods of heating: * Water circulates within the system at low temperatures (35 °C - 50 °C) making gas boilers, wood fired boilers, and heat pumps significantly more efficient. * Rooms with underfloor heating are cooler near the ceiling, where heat is not required, but warmer underfoot, where comfort is most required. * Traditional radiators are frequently positioned underneath poorly insulated windows, heating them unnecessarily. === Waste-water heat recovery === [[File:Hot water heat recycling unit.jpg|thumb|right|Recycling heat.]] It is possible to recover significant amounts of heat from waste hot water via [[hot water heat recycling]]. Major consumption of hot water is sinks, showers, baths, dishwashers, and clothes washers. On average 30% of a property's domestic hot water is used for showering.http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy10osti/47685.pdf pg5 Incoming fresh water is typically of a far lower temperature than the waste water from a shower. An inexpensive heat exchanger recovers up on average 40% of the heat that would normally be wasted, by warming incoming cold fresh water with heat from outgoing waste water. == See also == {{colbegin}} * [[Air source heat pumps]] * [[Autonomous building]] * [[Architectural engineering]] * [[Biogas]] * [[Energy conservation]] * [[Ground source heat pump]] * [[Green architecture]] * [[Green building]] * [[Hot water heat recycling]] * [[Superinsulation]] * [[Sustainability]] * [[Sustainable design]] * [[Mitigation of global warming]] * [[Natural building]] * [[Passive house]] * [[Passive solar]] * [[Renewable energy]] * [[Renewable energy development]] * [[Solar Air Heat]] * [[Solar combisystem]] * [[Solar hot water]] * [[Solar power]] * [[European Biomass Association]] * [[Thermal insulation]] * [[Underfloor heating]] * [[Wood briquette]]s * [[Zero energy building]] {{colend}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * Heat pumps based on R744 (CO2) [https://web.archive.org/web/20071006101017/http://www.r744.com/knowledge/faq_a.php FAQ] * [http://www.hptcj.or.jp/about_e/contribution/pdf/hpe-all.pdf Heat pumps Long Awaited Way out of the Global Warming] -
