page.title: Tropical cyclones and tornadoes in Pakistan

revision.text:
[[File:1999karachicyclone.jpg|thumb|Cyclone 2A making landfall near Karachi at peak intensity as Category-3 Hurricane in May 1999]] The '''tropical cyclones and tornadoes in Pakistan''' include the deadliest cyclone to hit the country and the deadliest tornado to struck the country. Pakistan lies in the [[temperate zone]]. The climate is generally arid, characterized by the extreme south western part of the country where [[Gwadar]] is the main port city. Though cyclones are rare in the Arabian sea which a part of North Indian Ocean, cyclones that form in this sea mostly move towards [[Western India]] rather than Pakistan.http://www.imd.gov.in/section/nhac/static/cyclone-history-as.htm Cyclones in the Arabian sea form mostly from May till June and then from September till October, [[monsoon]] season plays a vital role for the formation of cyclone in this basin. Tropical storms that hit Pakistan are mostly remnants by the time reach Pakistan or make landfall in south eastern [[Sindh]] which is not very much populated they rarely move towards the [[Balochistan]] coast. ==List of tropical cyclones in Pakistan== Pakistan has a 1,046-kilometre (650 mi) coastline along the [[Arabian Sea]]http://www.indexmundi.com/pakistan/coastline.html and the Gulf of Oman in the extreme south western part of the country where [[Gwadar]] is the main port city. Though cyclones are rare in the Arabian sea which is a part of North Indian Ocean, cyclones that form in this sea mostly move towards[[Western India]] rather than Pakistan. Cyclones in the Arabian sea form mostly from May till June and then from September till October, [[monsoon]] season plays a vital role for the formation of cyclone in this basin.http://www.associatepublisher.com/e/t/tr/tropical_cyclone.htm Each year before the onset of monsoon that is '''15 April to 15 July''' and also after its withdrawal that is '''15 September to 15 December''', there is always a distinct possibility of the cyclonic storm to develop in the north Arabian Sea.http://indianweatherman.blogspot.com/2010/06/cyclone-history-for-karachi.html There is a 98 per cent chance of cyclones to turn towards the Indian state of Gujarat, one per cent chance of moving towards the Gulf and one per cent chance of moving towards the Pakistani coast.http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/MYAI-86495X?OpenDocument There is only one tropical cyclone warning centre in Pakistan, which is in Karachi in Sindh province.http://www.pakmet.com.pk/ [[File:Cyclone 03B 26 jun 2007 0650Z.jpg|thumb|right|Cyclone Yemyin making landfall in Balochistan province on 26 June 2007]] Cyclones mostly hit the Sindh coast than the Balochistan coast in Pakistan. During the last 100 years a number of cyclonic storms have struck Pakistan's coastal areas. The years involved were 1895, 1902, 1907, 1944, 1948, 1964, 1985, 1999, 2007 and 2010. Other cyclones that are listed below caused rains as remnants. ===Pre-1900=== *10 July 1894 – A land depression moved westward through India, entering current-day Pakistan at Sindh.http://atms.unca.edu/ibtracs/ibtracs_v03r04/browse-ibtracs/index.php?name=v03r04-1894184N25089 *18 June 1895 – A cyclonic storm hit the [[Makran]] coast in [[Balochistan]] province. ===1900-691949=== *3 May 1901 – Originating off the southwest coast of India, a cyclone passed near Oman before making landfall along Balochistan. The storm moved through the country and dissipated on 5 May.{{cite report|author=Knapp, K. R.|author2=M. C. Kruk|author3=D. H. Levinson|author4=H. J. Diamond|author5=C. J. Neumann|year=2010|work=The International Best Track Archive for Climate Stewardship (IBTrACS): Unifying tropical cyclone best track data|title=1901 Missing (1901115N06074)|publisher=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|accessdate=January 22, 2016|url=http://atms.unca.edu/ibtracs/ibtracs_v03r04/browse-ibtracs/index.php?name=v03r04-1901115N06074}} *May 1902 – A cyclonic storm struck the coast in the vicinity of Karachi. *June 1907 – A tropical storm struck the coast near Karachi. *27 July 1944 – A [[Pre-1980 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons#July 1944 Karachi cyclone|cyclone]] left some 10,000 people homeless in Karachi. *8 June 1948 – Moving ashore near [[Pasni (city)|Pasni]] along the Makran, a storm brought rainfall to Balochistan and Sindh.https://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/cd020_pdf/00471F08.pdfhttp://atms.unca.edu/ibtracs/ibtracs_v03r04/browse-ibtracs/index.php?name=v03r04-1948157N17063 ===1950-1999=== *12 June 1964 – [[Pre-1980 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons#1964 Indus valley cyclone|A cyclone]] made landfall in [[Tharparkar]] and Hyderabad district in [[Sindh]] province. It killed 450 people and left some 400,000 people homeless.http://www.ndma.gov.pk/Publications/livingwithdisasters.pdf *15 December 1965 – [[Pre-1980 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons#December 1965 Karachi cyclone|A cyclone]] struck Karachi, killing 10,000 people. It is the deadliest cyclone on record in Pakistan.http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1498 *May 1985 – A [[1985–1989 North Indian Ocean cyclone seasons#Tropical Storm Two (2A)|cyclonic storm]] made a landfall in the eastern direction of Karachi. The cyclonic storm in 1985 which was moving towards Karachi actually had weakened over the sea while still a few 100 Kilometers away south of Karachi.http://www.wxp.unisys.com/hurricane/n_indian/1985/index.html *16 November 1993 – A cyclone dissipated near the Sindh-Gujarat border. However it caused massive rainfall and flooding in Karachi but Thatta and Badin districts were the worst affected where the cyclone killed 609 people and displaced some 200,000 others.http://arabnews.com/world/article60813.ece *9 June 1998 – Striking Gujarat in neighboring India, a [[1998 Gujarat cyclone|cyclone]] electrocuted 12 people in Pakistan.{{cite web|author=Gary Padgett|publisher=Typhoon 2000|date=July 14, 1998|accessdate=February 9, 2009|title=Monthly Tropical Cyclone Summary for June 1998|url=http://www.typhoon2000.ph/jun98.txt}} *20 May 1999 – The [[1999 Pakistan cyclone|strongest cyclone]] to hit Pakistan moved ashore near [[Keti Bandar]] at Category 3 intensity on the Saffir-Simpson scale. It killed 6,200 people in the country. At least $1 million in relief funds was to be supplied by the government.https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-zgcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tFkEAAAAIBAJ&dq=pakistan%20cyclone&pg=5489%2C512207 ===2000-present=== [[File:Phet jun 6 2010.jpg|thumb|Cyclone Phet making second landfall near Karachi on 6 June 2010]] *May 2001 – More than 100,000 people evacuated in southeastern Pakistan due to the threat from a [[2001 India cyclone|powerful cyclone]] in the Arabian Sea.{{cite web|author=Agence France-Presse|publisher=ReliefWeb|date=May 29, 2001|accessdate=December 13, 2009|title=100,000 Pakistanis who fled storm to return home|url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900sid/ACOS-64CAKF?OpenDocument&rc=3&emid=ST-2001-0729-IND}} The storm struck Gujarat as a weakened cyclone on 29 May.{{cite web|author=Joint Typhoon Warning Center|publisher=Naval Meteorology and Oceanography Command|year=2002|accessdate=June 3, 2010|title=Cyclone 01A Best Track|url=http://www.usno.navy.mil/NOOC/nmfc-ph/RSS/jtwc/best_tracks/2001/2001s-bio/bio012001.txt}} *1 October 2004 – [[Cyclone Onil]] became the first named storm in the Indian Ocean, and meandered for several days off the coast of Gujarat. In Pakistan, Onil brought heavy rainfall and gusty winds.{{cite web|author=Gary Padgett|publisher=Australia Severe Weather|date=May 17, 2005|accessdate=June 10, 2010|title=Monthly Tropical Weather Summary for October 2004|url=http://australiasevereweather.com/cyclones/2005/summ0410.htm}} In Karachi, nine people died from the storm, as flooded streets and power outages contributed to at least two electrocution deaths.{{cite web|author=Staff Writer|publisher=Associated Press|date=October 3, 2004|accessdate=June 10, 2010|title=A cyclone in southern Pakistan kills nine people|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-100197767.html}} *June 2007 – Powerful [[Cyclone Gonu]] remained well southwest of Pakistan, but it still produced heavy rainfall and strong winds in the city of Gwadar in Balochistan, where it caused damage to dozens of boats and school buildings in the area. It also caused high winds with light rainfall in Karachi and other coastal areas.http://www.woeurope.eu/cgi-app/reports?ARCHIV=1&LANG=eu&MENU=207&FILE=b1.txt&DAY=20070607&JJA=2007&MMA=06&TTA=08http://archives.dawn.com/2007/06/06/local16.htm *23 June 2007 – [[Cyclone Yemyin]], which developed over the [[Bay of Bengal]] and intensified into a cyclone over the Arabian Sea, killed 200 people alone in Karachi city due to heavy rainfall and intense windstorms as it was moving towards Balochistan province.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/6233868.stm | work=BBC News | title=Storms in Karachi kill 200 people | date=24 June 2007}} It made landfall near the towns of [[Ormara]] and [[Pasni (city)|Pasni]] in the Balochistan province on 26 June where it killed 300 people.https://www.webcitation.org/5PsfixNqs Overall it killed 730 people and affected the lives of 2 million people in Pakistan making it the third deadliest cyclone in the history of the country.http://www.emdat.be/disaster-list *In November 2009, remnants of [[Cyclone Phyan]] caused gusty winds along the Sindh coast including Karachi. However six Pakistani fishermen were trapped in the storm later rescued by the [[Indian Navy]].http://videosfromindia.smashits.com/view/10962/rescued-pak-teenagers-of-phyan-cyclone-seek-early-repatriation&page=1&viewtype=&category=mr *6 June 2010 – [[Cyclone Phet]] made landfall near Karachi as a depression,{{cite report|editor=B.K. Bandyopadhyay|pages=40, 54–55, 115–129|title=WMO/ESCAP Panel on Tropical Cyclones Annual Review 2010|year=2011|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|url=http://www.rsmcnewdelhi.imd.gov.in/images/pdf/publications/annual-cyclone-review/annual-review-2010.pdf|format=PDF}} having earlier dropped heavy rainfall along the Makran coast. [[Gwadar]] recorded {{convert|370|mm|in|abbr=on}} of rainfall,{{cite report|year=2011|title=WMO/ESCAP Panel on Tropical Cyclones Thirty-Eighth Session|publisher=World Meteorological Organization|accessdate=September 11, 2016|at=Appendix VII|chapter=Country Report of Pakistan|url=https://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/PTC38_FinalReport-final_120220.pdf|format=PDF}} which damaged 10,000 houses,{{cite report|title=June 2010 Monthly Cat Recap –Impact Forecasting|publisher=AON Benfield|year=2010|accessdate=November 14, 2016|url=http://thoughtleadership.aonbenfield.com/documents/201006_if_monthly_cat_recap_june.pdf|format=PDF}} and disrupted portions of the [[Makran Coastal Highway]].{{cite news|agency=DAWN Group of Newspapers|author=Saleem Shahid|date=June 6, 2010|accessdate=September 15, 2016|publisher=ReliefWeb|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/pakistan/pakistan-heavy-rain-batters-gwadar-cyclone-eyes-karachi|title=Pakistan: Heavy rain batters Gwadar, cyclone eyes Karachi}} Phet killed at least 18 people in Pakistan – 11 by electrocution, and 7 due to collapsed walls.{{cite report|pages=31–32|url=http://www.ndma.gov.pk/Documents/Annual%20Report/NDMA%20Annual%20Report%202010.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=November 8, 2016|publisher=National Disaster Management Authority|title=Annual Report|editor1=Zeb-u-Nisa|editor2=Zahid Habib Bhutta|date=April 2011}} The storm also injured dozens of others and left thousands of Pakistanis homeless.{{cite news|author=Syed Moazzam Hashmi|title= Cyclone "Phet" leaves 15 dead, thousands homeless in Pakistan|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-06/07/c_13337519.htm|accessdate=November 8, 2016|agency=Xinhua|date=June 7, 2010}} Damage was estimated at [[Pakistani rupee|RS]]7 billion (US$80 million). *November 2010 – The remnants of [[Cyclone Jal]] caused dusty winds in Karachi while it caused light to moderate rainfall in southeastern [[Sindh]].http://www.pakmet.com.pk/Pakistan%20Weather%20outlook/WxReportDaily.htmlhttp://dawnnews.tv/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/local/gusty-winds-lash-city-010 ===Wettest tropical cyclone of Pakistan=== {| class="wikitable" border="10" style="font-size: 92%;" |- ! colspan=5 style="background:#cff;" | Wettest tropical cyclones/depressions in Pakistan
Highest known recorded totals |- ! colspan=3 width="24%"| Precipitation ! rowspan=2 width="12%"| Storm ! rowspan=2 width="24%"| Measurement
station |- ! Rank ! ([[Millimetre|mm]]) ! ([[Inch|in]]) |- | 1 || 370 mm || 14.57 inches || [[Cyclone Phet|Phet (2010)]] || [[Gwadar]]http://www.centralasiaonline.com/cocoon/caii/xhtml/en_GB/newsbriefs/caii/newsbriefs/2010/06/04/newsbrief-04 |- | 2 || 285  mm || 11.22  inches || [[1999 Pakistan cyclone|Cyclone (1999)]] || [[Keti Bandar]]http://www.heatisonline.org/contentserver/objecthandlers/index.cfm?id=3330&method=full |- | 3 || 245 mm || 9.64 inches || [[2009 North Indian Ocean cyclone season#Depression BOB|BOB (2009)]] || [[Karachi]]http://www.pakmet.com.pk/FFD/cp/fr2009.pdfhttp://www.wunderground.com/history/airport/OPKC/2009/7/17/DailyHistory.htmlhttp://hamariweb.com/myreport/report.aspx?id=199 |- | 4 || 191 mm || 7.51 inches || [[2007 North Indian Ocean cyclone season#Deep Depression BOB 06|BOB 06 (2007)]] || [[Karachi]]http://www.accuweather.com/world-news-blogs.asp?blog=andrews&partner=accuweather&pgUrl=/mtweb/content/andrews/archives/2007/08/will_the_arabia.asphttps://www.webcitation.org/5QwDsh3rShttp://www.dawn.com/2007/08/12/local1.htm |- | 5 || 145 mm || 5.71 inches || [[Cyclone Onil|Onil (2004)]] || [[Thatta]]http://archives.dawn.com/dawnftp/72.249.57.55/dawnftp/fixed/arch/arch_2004/arch_oct_04.htm |- | 6 || 110 mm || 3.94 inches || [[Cyclone Yemyin|Yemyin (2007)]] || [[Karachi]] |- | 7 || 43 mm || 1.69 inches || [[2007 North Indian Ocean cyclone season#Deep Depression BOB 04|BOB 04 (2007)]] || [[Karachi]]https://www.webcitation.org/5Q0T8juTqhttp://www.dawn.com/2007/07/01/local2.htm |- | 8 || 18 mm || 0.70 inches || [[2009 North Indian Ocean cyclone season#Deep Depression BOB 03|BOB 03 (2009)]] || [[Karachi]]http://news.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/the-newspaper/local/karachi-heavy-rains-forecast-579 |} ==Tornadoes in Pakistan== Tornadoes have been reported almost all over the Indian subcontinent with most in Bangladesh and eastern India.http://www.sky-fire.tv/index.cgi/tornadoes.html However, [[dust devil]]s are common in Pakistan, particularly in the northern and central parts of the country. Tornadoes are highly uncommon in Pakistan, where they mostly occur in March and April when a [[Western Disturbance]] starts effecting the northern parts of the country.http://www.angelfire.com/az3/azt_articles/wtrphenomena/chak_misran.html It is also speculated that cycles of tornado years may be correlated to the periods of reduced tropical cyclone activity{{cite journal | url = http://www.springerlink.com/content/252m78qj82042665/ | doi=10.1007/BF02263310 | volume=29 | title=Climatology of tornadoes of India and Bangladesh | year=1981 | journal=Archives for Meteorology, Geophysics, and Bioclimatology Series B | pages=345–356 | author=Peterson R. E.}} Following is a list of tornadoes which struck the country. *On 10 March 1981, a killer tornado killed some 56 people and injured 600 people in [[Gujranwala]] and [[Sheikhupura]] districts of Punjab province. *On 10 March 1985, a tornado killed 18 people in the northern areas of the country. *In 1995, hundred people were reported to have been killed by a tornado in Pakistan. *On 28 March 2001, a killer tornado killed 10 people and injured some 100 people in Chak Misran village near Bhalwal area in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Punjab]] province. The tornado had surface winds greater than 75 mph. It uprooted electric poles and bill boards in the area. *Another Tornado hit Narang Mangi near [[Narowal]] city in Punjab province but no relevant data is available about this tornado.https://www.scribd.com/doc/45609806/Tornadoes-in-Pakistan ==See also== *[[List of Asian tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] *[[List of wettest tropical cyclones by country]] *[[List of Arabian Peninsula tropical cyclones]] ;Weather in Pakistan *[[Climate of Pakistan]] *[[Drought in Pakistan]] *[[List of floods in Pakistan]] *[[List of extreme weather records in Pakistan]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.pakmet.com.pk/ Pakistan Meteorological Department] {{Pakistan topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Tropical Cyclones And Tornadoes In Pakistan}} [[Category:Tropical cyclones in Pakistan| 01]] [[Category:Lists of tropical cyclones|Pakistan]] [[Category:Lists of tropical cyclones by area|Pakistan]] [[Category:Climate of Pakistan]] [[Category:Environment of Pakistan]] [[Category:Tropical cyclone meteorology]] [[Category:Weather events in Pakistan]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=December 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox zoo |zoo_name= Underwater World |logo=Underwater_World_Singapore_logo.jpg |logo_width= |logo_caption= |image= Underwater World, Singapore 4, Sentosa, Aug 06.JPG |image_width= |image_caption= Entrance to Underwater World |date_opened= 13 May 1991 |date_closed= 26 June 2016 |location= Sentosa, Singapore |area= {{Convert|28|ha}} |coordinates= |num_animals= 2500 |num_species= 250 |members= |exhibits= Aquatic Creatures |website= {{URL|http://www.underwaterworld.com.sg/}} }}
'''Underwater World''' ([[Simplified Chinese characters|Chinese]]: 新加坡海底世界) (13 May 1991 – 26 June 2016),<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/underwater-world/2848824.html |title=Underwater World Singapore to close Jun 26 |author=Channel NewsAsia |work=Channel NewsAsia |publisher=[[Channel NewsAsia]] |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> also known as Underwater World Singapore Pte Ltd, was an [[oceanarium]] located on the offshore Singaporean island of [[Sentosa]]. Opened in 1991, it had more than 2,500 [[marine animal]]s of 250 species from different regions of the world. The oceanarium was mostly underground and it was owned by the [[Haw Par Corporation]]. The Underwater World's ticket included admission to the Dolphin Lagoon at Palawan Beach.
Underwater World was also involved in several environmental and educational projects, such as the Living in the Ocean Programme, Ocean Ambassador Programme and the Coral Club.
The Underwater World also provided exclusive venues to host events, such as ocean-themed functions.
On 6 June 2016, it was announced by operator Haw Par that the venue would close on 26 June 2016, Its pink dolphins, fur seals and otters had been transferred to [[Chimelong Ocean Kingdom]] in Zhuhai, China the week before the announcement.<ref name="Revamp">{{cite web |url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/underwater-world/2848824.html |title=Underwater World Singapore to close Jun 26 |date=6 June 2016 |work=[[Channel News Asia]] |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
==History== The oceanarium was opened to the public on 13 May 1991.<ref name="Revamp2">{{cite web |url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_1855_2011-11-11.html |title=Underwater World Singapore |date=6 June 2016 |work=[[NLB E-Resources]] |accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> It re-opened on 23 February 2010 after a revamp of several attractions within the park.<ref name="Revamp3">{{cite web |url=http://www.straitstimes.com/BreakingNews/Singapore/Story/STIStory_494078.html |title=Underwater World revamped |date=23 February 2010 |work=[[The Straits Times]] |accessdate=20 October 2010}}</ref> [[Underwater World Monorail Station]] used to serve this attraction, but it no longer does since the station closed in 2005.
==Attractions== Underwater World had a {{convert|83|m|sing=on}} long [[Moving walkway|travelator]] that moved visitors along a submerged {{convert|6|mm|sing=on}} thick [[Shark tunnel|acrylic-windowed tunnel]] from which they could look at an array of marine life including [[coral reef]]s, [[Batoidea|stingray]]s, [[moray eel]]s, [[turtles]], [[shark]]s and others.
===Adventures=== The Underwater World and Dolphin Lagoon offered numerous adventures to the visitors. Some of them included: *Marine Discovery *Dive With the Sharks *Swim With the Dolphins<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.underwaterworld.com.sg/adventures.htm |title=Underwater World – Adventures |author=Underwater World Staff |work=Underwater World |publisher=[[Haw Par Corporation]] |accessdate=20 October 2010}}</ref>
===Dolphin Lagoon=== [[Image:Sentosabdolphinc.JPG|thumb|Dolphin performing an agile feat at the Dolphin Lagoon]] The Dolphin Lagoon was home to several [[Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin]]s, also known as the "pink dolphins". Several "Meet-the-Dolphins" sessions were held daily that allowed visitors to enter the waist-deep pool and interact closely with the dolphins. The ticket to the Underwater World & dolphin show did not include the direct contact with the dolphins, an additional photo-coupon had to be purchased. The lagoon also included a Dolphin Suite where visitors could watch the dolphin performance from within an air-conditioned area.<ref name="Revamp"/>
In August 2014 the organizations Wildlife Watcher Singapore, in collaboration with Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, disclosed severe mistreatment of the dolphins in the Lagoon [https://www.dropbox.com/s/t0b9xjaezzv2nyi/DolphinLagoonUWSSingapore.pdf?dl=0 in a report].
The pink dolphins have since been rehoused in [[Chimelong Ocean Kingdom]], an oceanarium in [[Zhuhai]], [[China]].<ref>https://sg.news.yahoo.com/underwater-world-singapore-to-close-animals-sent-082700104.html</ref>
==Effect of plans for Sentosa Integrated Resort== On 6 December 2006, Underwater World Singapore launched three new attractions{{mdash}}an interactive stingray feeding pool, a display of small marine [[reef]] species, and 'Fish Reflexology', Singapore's first fish [[reflexology]] [[Balneotherapy|spa]], where two species of [[doctor fish]] gently nibble away at the dead skin on visitors' feet. The new features cost {{dollarsign|SGD}}650,000.
This was amid plans that were being proposed for Sentosa's [[Integrated Resort]]s. [[Genting Group]]'s {{dollarsign|SGD}}5.2 billion proposal, Resorts World, would feature the world's largest oceanarium at that point in time{{mdash}}the {{Convert|8|ha|sing=on}} Quest Marine Life Park{{mdash}}which would house 700,000 marine animals in a {{Convert|30000000|l|-3|sing=on}} lagoon. Rival [[bidding|bidder]] [[Sol Kerzner|Kerzner]]-[[CapitaLand]]'s proposal would have an even larger marine habitat, with a capacity of {{Convert|109000000|l|-3}}, including the world's largest [[jellyfish]] enclosure and an [[artificial reef]] for [[Underwater diving|diving]] and [[snorkelling]].<ref name="Jessica Cheam">Jessica Cheam, "Underwater World not threatened by IR plans", ''[[The Straits Times]]'', 7 December 2006</ref> A week later it was announced that Genting International won the bid. In 2012, the [[Marine Life Park]] (also known as S.E.A. Aquarium) opened in [[Resorts World Sentosa]].
==List of animals in Underwater World and Dolphin Lagoon== [[Image:Sentosaaunderwaterx.JPG|thumb|Sharks at Underwater World]] [[File:Indo-Pacific humpbacked dolphin jumping.jpg|thumb|Indo-Pacific humpbacked dolphin performing at Dolphin Lagoon]] *[[Golden Trevally]] *[[Bluespotted ribbontail ray]] *[[Indo-Pacific Humpback Dolphin]] *[[Coconut Crab]] *[[Cownose Ray]] *[[Dugong]] (''Dugong dugon'') *Moon Jellyfish (''[[Aurelia aurita]]'') *[[Spider Crab]] *[[Yellow Tang]] *[[Sand tiger shark]] *[[Green Sea Turtle]] *[[Doctor fish|Nibble Fish]] *all kinds of reef fish *[[Pufferfish]] *[[Sea Star]]s/Starfishes *[[Chambered Nautilus]] *[[Arapaima]] *[[Angel shark]] *[[Bannerfish]]es *[[Butterfly Fish]]es *[[Cardisoma armatum|Rainbow Crab]] *[[Episesarma|Vinegar crab]] *[[Calappa (crab)|Box Crabs]] *[[Decorator Crab]] *[[Humphead Wrasse]] *[[Guitarfish|Shovelnose Rays]] *[[Eagle ray|Eagle Rays]] *[[Nurse Shark]]s *[[Bamboo Shark]]s *[[Leafy seadragon]] *[[Weedy seadragon]] *[[Clown fish]]es *[[Sea Anemone]]s *[[Giant Grouper]] *[[Whitetip reef shark|White-tip reef shark]] *[[Leopard Shark]] *[[Lion's Mane Jellyfish]] *[[Jelly blubber|Blue Jellyfish]] *[[Chrysaora|Sea Nettle]]
==See also== *[[Jurong Bird Park]] *[[Night Safari]] *[[Marine Life Park]] *[[Singapore Zoo]] *[[Van Kleef Aquarium]]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}

{{Infobox deity | type = hindu | image = Panchchuli II at dawn.jpg |Devanagari=उषस् |deity_of=Goddess of Dawn and Shining Morning |mount=Golden Chariot |affiliation=[[Devi]] |abode=[[Sun]] |texts = Rigveda |Greek_equivalent=[[Eos]] |Roman_equivalent=[[Aurora (mythology)|Aurora]] |consort = [[Surya]] |children = [[Ashvins]] |siblings=[[Ratri]], [[Nindra]], [[Chandra]] |mantra = Om Ushaaya Namah{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} }} {{Hinduism}} '''Ushas''' ([[Vedic Sanskrit]]: {{lang|sa|उषस्}} / ''{{IAST|uṣás}}'') is a [[Vedas|Vedic]] goddess of [[dawn]] in [[Hinduism]].{{cite book|author1=Constance Jones|author2=James D. Ryan|title=Encyclopedia of Hinduism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OgMmceadQ3gC&pg=PA472 |year= 2006| publisher= Infobase Publishing|isbn= 978-0-8160-7564-5|page=472}}{{citation|last=Apte |first=Vaman Shivram |title=The Practical Sanskrit Dictionary |year=1965 |publisher=Motilal Banarsidass |location=New Delhi |isbn=81-208-0567-4|edition=4th}}, p. 304. She repeatedly appears in the Rigvedic hymns, states David Kinsley, where she is "consistently identified with dawn, revealing herself with the daily coming of light to the world, driving away oppressive darkness, chasing away evil demons, rousing all life, setting all things in motion, sending everyone off to do their duties". She is the life of all living creatures, the impeller of action and breath, the foe of chaos and confusion, the auspicious arouser of cosmic and moral order called the [[Ṛta]] in Hinduism.{{cite book|author=David Kinsley|title=Hindu Goddesses: Visions of the Divine Feminine in the Hindu Religious Tradition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HzldwMHeS6IC |year=1988|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-90883-3|pages=7–8}} Ushas is the most exalted goddess in the ''[[Rig Veda]]'', but not as important or central as the three male Vedic deities [[Agni]], [[Soma (deity)|Soma]] and [[Indra]].{{cite book|author=David Kinsley| title= Hindu Goddesses: Visions of the Divine Feminine in the Hindu Religious Tradition|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=HzldwMHeS6IC |year= 1988|publisher= University of California Press|isbn= 978-0-520-90883-3|pages= 6–7}} She is on par with other major male Vedic deities. She is portrayed as a beautifully adorned young woman riding in a golden chariot or a hundred chariots, drawn by golden red horses or cows, on her path across the sky, making way for the Vedic sun god [[Surya]].[[F B J Kuiper|Kuiper, F.B.J.]] (1968). ''Ancient Indian Cosmogony''. Bombay 1983. Schmidt, H.P. ''Brhaspati und Indra''. Wiesbaden 1968. Some of the most beautiful hymns in the Vedas are dedicated to her.{{cite book|author=Peter Heehs|title=Indian Religions: A Historical Reader of Spiritual Expression and Experience|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jgsu-aIm3ncC |year=2002|publisher=New York University Press|isbn=978-0-8147-3650-0|pages=44–45}}{{cite book|author=W. J. Wilkins|title=Hindu Gods and Goddesses|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=f0XpDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA48 |year=2003|publisher=Courier|isbn=978-0-486-43156-7|pages=48–52}} Her sister is ''Ratri'', or the night. == Etymology == Vedic ''{{IAST|uṣás}}'' is derived from the word ''uṣá'' which means "dawn". This word comes from [[Proto-Indo-Iranian language|Proto-Indo-Iranian]] [[wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Indo-Iranian/Hušā́s|''*Hušā́s'']] ("ušā" in Avestan), which in turn is from [[Proto-Indo-European language|Proto-Indo-European]] [[Hausos|''*h₂éusōs'']] ("dawn"), and is related to "héōs" in Greek and "aušrà" in Lithuanian. It is also the basis for the word "east" in Indo-European traditions, state Mallory and Adams.{{cite book|last1=Mallory|first1=J.P.|last2=Adams|first2=D.Q.|title=The Oxford Introduction to Proto-Indo-European and the Proto-Indo-European World|year =2006| publisher= Oxford University Press|location =Oxford |isbn= 978-0-19-929668-2|page= 301}} ''Uṣás'' is an ''s''-stem, i.e. the genitive case is ''{{IAST|uṣásas}}'', whereby it connotes "dawn goddess" in [[Indo-European languages]].{{cite book|last1=Mallory |first1=J.P.|last2=Adams |first2=D.Q.|title= The Oxford Introduction to Proto-Indo-European and the Proto-Indo-European World|year =2006| publisher= Oxford University Press|location =Oxford |isbn= 978-0-19-929668-2|page= 409}} Ushas is related to the [[Proto-Indo-European religion|Proto-Indo-European goddess]] ''{{PIE|*[[h₂ausos]]-}}''. Her cognates in other Indo-European pantheons include the Greek goddess [[Eos (mythology)|Eos]], the Roman goddess [[Aurora (mythology)|Aurora]], the Lithuanian goddess [[Austrine]], and the English goddess [[Ēostre]] (OE: ēastre), whose name is probably the root of the modern English word "[[Easter]]."{{cite book|last1=Mallory|first1=J.P.|last2=Adams|first2=D.Q.|title=The Oxford Introduction to Proto-Indo-European and the Proto-Indo-European World|year=2006|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford, England|isbn=978-0-19-929668-2|page=432}} ==Description== Ushas is the prominent goddess of dawn in the Vedas. She is depicted as the one who imbues life to all beings, as the "life of all life" and "breath of all breaths", according to Jones and Ryan. She is revered as the deity who revivifies earth each day, drives away the chaos and the darkness, sets all things in motion, sends all living beings to do their duties in the Vedas. Ushas is the most important goddess in the Vedic literature, but she is not as important as the three central male deities named [[Agni]], [[Soma (deity)|Soma]] and [[Indra]]. She is mentioned in far less number of hymns than these three, but nearly equal or more number of hymns than all other male and female deities in the Vedas.{{cite book|author=David Kinsley|title=Hindu Goddesses: Visions of the Divine Feminine in the Hindu Religious Tradition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HzldwMHeS6IC |year=1988|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-90883-3|pages=6–8}} === Rig Veda === Ushas is mentioned in numerous hymns of the ''Rigveda''. Forty of its hymns are dedicated to her, while her name appears in other additional hymns.{{cite book|author=Roshen Dalal|title=Hinduism: An Alphabetical Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DH0vmD8ghdMC |year=2010|publisher=Penguin |isbn=978-0-14-341421-6|page=433}} She is thanked for and petitioned for driving away darkness in hymns 7.78, 6.64 and 10.172; bringer of light urged by Surya in hymn 3.61, and the chaser of evil demons in hymn 8.47. The Rigvedic hymn 1.48 describes her as drawn in a hundred chariots, revealed by the daily arrival of light, one who sets all motion to life and all life to motion, rousing people off to their duties. She is revered for giving strength in hymn 1.44, to [[Ṛta]] in hymn 3.61 and 7.75, and participating in daily restoration of order and fighting chaotic forces that threaten the world in hymn 1.113. Ushas is described in Vedic texts as riding in a shining chariot drawn by golden-red horses or cows, a beautiful maiden bedecked with jewels, smiling and irresistibly attractive, who brings cheer to all those who gaze upon her. She dispels darkness, reveals treasures and truths that have been hidden, illuminates the world as it is. Hymn 6.64 associates her with wealth and light, while hymn 1.92 calls her the "mother of cows" and one, who like a cow, gives to the benefit of all people. Hymn 1.113 calls her "mother of the gods", while hymn 7.81 states her to be the mother of all living beings who petition her. She is the goddess of the hearth, states hymn 6.64. She symbolizes reality, is a marker of time and a reminder to all that "life is limited on earth". She sees everything as it is, and she is the eye of the gods, according to hymns 7.75–77. She is variously mentioned as the sister of Ratri (night),{{cite book|author=David Kinsley| title= Hindu Goddesses: Visions of the Divine Feminine in the Hindu Religious Tradition |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=HzldwMHeS6IC |year= 1988|publisher= University of California Press|isbn= 978-0-520-90883-3|page= 14}} Aditya and one who goes about her ways closely with deities Savitri and Surya. She is also associated with [[Varuna]] (sky, water) and Agni (fire).{{cite book|author=George M. Williams|title=Handbook of Hindu Mythology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N7LOZfwCDpEC |year=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press |isbn=978-0-19-533261-2|pages=287–288}} In RV 6.64.1-2 (trans. [[Ralph T.H. Griffith|Griffith]]), Ushas is invoked as follows:[https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Rig_Veda/Mandala_6/Hymn_64 The Rig Veda, Mandala 6], Hymn 64, Ralph T.H. Griffith, Wikisource # ''The radiant Dawns have risen up for glory, in their white splendour like the waves of waters.''
''She maketh paths all easy, fair to travel, and, rich, hath shown herself benign and friendly.'' # ''We see that thou art good: far shines thy lustre; thy beams, thy splendours have flown up to heaven.''
''Decking thyself, thou makest bare thy bosom, shining in majesty, thou Goddess Morning.'' In the "family books" of the ''Rig Veda'' (e.g. [[RV 6]].64.5), Ushas is the divine daughter—a ''{{IAST|divó duhitâ}}'' —of ''[[Dyaus Pita]]'' ("Sky Father"). This is taken literally in the traditional genealogies of [[Hindu mythology]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} == Contemporary reverence == The revered [[Gayatri mantra]], states George Williams, remains a daily reminder of Ushas in contemporary Hinduism. According to Sri [[Aurobindo]], Ushas is "the medium of the awakening, the activity and the growth of the other gods; she is the first condition of the Vedic realisation. By her increasing illumination the whole nature of man is clarified; through her [mankind] arrives at the Truth, through her he enjoys [Truth's] beatitude."{{citation|author=Sri Aurobindo|title=Secret of the Veda|publisher=Lotus Press|location=Twin Lakes|isbn=0-914955-19-5|year=1995}}, p. 283. Ushas is regionally worshipped during the festival of [[Chhath Puja]], in [[Bihar]] and [[Uttar Pradesh]] ([[India]]), and in [[Nepal]].{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} ==See also== *[[Chhaya]] *[[Ēostre]] *[[Ratri]] *[[Surya]] *[[Saranyu]] *[[Shani]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book|last=Dallapiccola|first = Anna|title = Dictionary of Hindu Lore and Legend|isbn = 0-500-51088-1 | location = New York | publisher = Thames & Hudson | year = 2002 }} * {{cite book | last=Kinsley| first=David | title = Hindu Goddesses: Vision of the Divine Feminine in the Hindu Religious Traditions | isbn = 81-208-0379-5 | year = 1987 |location=New Delhi | publisher = Motilal Banarsidass }} {{Hindudharma}} {{Rigveda}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Hindu goddesses]] [[Category:Rigvedic deities]] [[Category:Solar goddesses]] [[Category:Hausos]] [[Category:Hinduism and cattle]] [[Category:Dawn]]
